    5931           0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    5932           0 : }
    5933             : 
    5934             : /*
    5935             :  * When recovery_min_apply_delay is set, we wait long enough to make sure
    5936             :  * certain record types are applied at least that interval behind the master.
    5937             :  *
    5938             :  * Returns true if we waited.
    5939             :  *
    5940             :  * Note that the delay is calculated between the WAL record log time and
    5941             :  * the current time on standby. We would prefer to keep track of when this
    5942             :  * standby received each WAL record, which would allow a more consistent
    5943             :  * approach and one not affected by time synchronisation issues, but that
    5944             :  * is significantly more effort and complexity for little actual gain in
    5945             :  * usability.
    5946             :  */
    5947             : static bool
    5948           0 : recoveryApplyDelay(XLogReaderState *record)
    5949             : {
    5950             :     uint8       xact_info;
    5951             :     TimestampTz xtime;
    5952             :     long        secs;
    5953             :     int         microsecs;
    5954             : 
    5955             :     /* nothing to do if no delay configured */
    5956           0 :     if (recovery_min_apply_delay <= 0)
    5957           0 :         return false;
    5958             : 
    5959             :     /* no delay is applied on a database not yet consistent */
    5960           0 :     if (!reachedConsistency)
    5961           0 :         return false;
    5962             : 
    5963             :     /* nothing to do if crash recovery is requested */
    5964           0 :     if (!ArchiveRecoveryRequested)
    5965           0 :         return false;
    5966             : 
    5967             :     /*
    5968             :      * Is it a COMMIT record?
    5969             :      *
    5970             :      * We deliberately choose not to delay aborts since they have no effect on
    5971             :      * MVCC. We already allow replay of records that don't have a timestamp,
    5972             :      * so there is already opportunity for issues caused by early conflicts on
    5973             :      * standbys.
    5974             :      */
    5975           0 :     if (XLogRecGetRmid(record) != RM_XACT_ID)
    5976           0 :         return false;
    5977             : 
    5978           0 :     xact_info = XLogRecGetInfo(record) & XLOG_XACT_OPMASK;
    5979             : 
    5980           0 :     if (xact_info != XLOG_XACT_COMMIT &&
    5981             :         xact_info != XLOG_XACT_COMMIT_PREPARED)
    5982           0 :         return false;
    5983             : 
    5984           0 :     if (!getRecordTimestamp(record, &xtime))
    5985           0 :         return false;
    5986             : 
    5987           0 :     recoveryDelayUntilTime =
    5988           0 :         TimestampTzPlusMilliseconds(xtime, recovery_min_apply_delay);
    5989             : 
    5990             :     /*
    5991             :      * Exit without arming the latch if it's already past time to apply this
    5992             :      * record
    5993             :      */
    5994           0 :     TimestampDifference(GetCurrentTimestamp(), recoveryDelayUntilTime,
    5995             :                         &secs, &microsecs);
    5996           0 :     if (secs <= 0 && microsecs <= 0)
    5997           0 :         return false;
    5998             : 
    5999             :     while (true)
    6000             :     {
    6001           0 :         ResetLatch(&XLogCtl->recoveryWakeupLatch);
    6002             : 
    6003             :         /* might change the trigger file's location */
    6004           0 :         HandleStartupProcInterrupts();
    6005             : 
    6006           0 :         if (CheckForStandbyTrigger())
    6007           0 :             break;
    6008             : 
    6009             :         /*
    6010             :          * Wait for difference between GetCurrentTimestamp() and
    6011             :          * recoveryDelayUntilTime
    6012             :          */
    6013           0 :         TimestampDifference(GetCurrentTimestamp(), recoveryDelayUntilTime,
    6014             :                             &secs, &microsecs);
    6015             : 
    6016             :         /*
    6017             :          * NB: We're ignoring waits below recovery_min_apply_delay's
    6018             :          * resolution.
    6019             :          */
    6020           0 :         if (secs <= 0 && microsecs / 1000 <= 0)
    6021           0 :             break;
    6022             : 
    6023           0 :         elog(DEBUG2, "recovery apply delay %ld seconds, %d milliseconds",
    6024             :              secs, microsecs / 1000);
    6025             : 
    6026           0 :         (void) WaitLatch(&XLogCtl->recoveryWakeupLatch,
    6027             :                          WL_LATCH_SET | WL_TIMEOUT | WL_EXIT_ON_PM_DEATH,
    6028           0 :                          secs * 1000L + microsecs / 1000,
    6029             :                          WAIT_EVENT_RECOVERY_APPLY_DELAY);
    6030           0 :     }
    6031           0 :     return true;
    6032             : }
    6033             : 
    6034             : /*
    6035             :  * Save timestamp of latest processed commit/abort record.
    6036             :  *
    6037             :  * We keep this in XLogCtl, not a simple static variable, so that it can be

    6115             : #define RecoveryRequiresIntParameter(param_name, currValue, minValue) \

    6132             :  * Note that all the parameters which this function tests need to be

    6206             : 
    6207             :     /*
    6208             :      * We should have an aux process resource owner to use, and we should not

    6210             :      */

    6213             :            CurrentResourceOwner == AuxProcessResourceOwner);
    6214           6 :     CurrentResourceOwner = AuxProcessResourceOwner;
    6215             : 
    6216             :     /*
    6217             :      * Check that contents look valid.
    6218             :      */
    6219           6 :     if (!XRecOffIsValid(ControlFile->checkPoint))
    6220           0 :         ereport(FATAL,
    6221             :                 (errmsg("control file contains invalid checkpoint location")));
    6222             : 
    6223           6 :     switch (ControlFile->state)
    6224             :     {
    6225             :         case DB_SHUTDOWNED:
    6226             :             /* This is the expected case, so don't be chatty in standalone mode */
    6227           6 :             ereport(IsPostmasterEnvironment ? LOG : NOTICE,

    6229             :                             str_time(ControlFile->time))));
    6230           6 :             break;
    6231             : 
    6232             :         case DB_SHUTDOWNED_IN_RECOVERY:
    6233           0 :             ereport(LOG,
    6234             :                     (errmsg("database system was shut down in recovery at %s",
    6235             :                             str_time(ControlFile->time))));

    6249             :                              " you will have to use the last backup for recovery.")));

    6271             :     /* This is just to allow attaching to startup process with a debugger */

    6277             :     /*

    6279             :      * someone has performed a copy for PITR, these directories may have been
    6280             :      * excluded and need to be re-created.

    6282           6 :     ValidateXLOGDirectoryStructure();
    6283             : 
    6284             :     /*----------
    6285             :      * If we previously crashed, perform a couple of actions:
    6286             :      *  - The pg_wal directory may still include some temporary WAL segments
    6287             :      * used when creating a new segment, so perform some clean up to not
    6288             :      * bloat this path.  This is done first as there is no point to sync this
    6289             :      * temporary data.
    6290             :      *  - There might be data which we had written, intending to fsync it,
    6291             :      * but which we had not actually fsync'd yet. Therefore, a power failure
    6292             :      * in the near future might cause earlier unflushed writes to be lost,
    6293             :      * even though more recent data written to disk from here on would be
    6294             :      * persisted.  To avoid that, fsync the entire data directory.
    6295             :      *---------
    6296             :      */
    6297           6 :     if (ControlFile->state != DB_SHUTDOWNED &&
    6298           0 :         ControlFile->state != DB_SHUTDOWNED_IN_RECOVERY)
    6299             :     {
    6300           0 :         RemoveTempXlogFiles();
    6301           0 :         SyncDataDirectory();
    6302             :     }
    6303             : 
    6304             :     /*
    6305             :      * Initialize on the assumption we want to recover to the latest timeline

    6361           6 :     if (!xlogreader)

    6365             :                  errdetail("Failed while allocating a WAL reading processor.")));
    6366           6 :     xlogreader->system_identifier = ControlFile->system_identifier;
    6367             : 
    6368             :     /*
    6369             :      * Allocate two page buffers dedicated to WAL consistency checks.  We do
    6370             :      * it this way, rather than just making static arrays, for two reasons:
    6371             :      * (1) no need to waste the storage in most instantiations of the backend;
    6372             :      * (2) a static char array isn't guaranteed to have any particular
    6373             :      * alignment, whereas palloc() will provide MAXALIGN'd storage.
    6374             :      */
    6375           6 :     replay_image_masked = (char *) palloc(BLCKSZ);
    6376           6 :     master_image_masked = (char *) palloc(BLCKSZ);
    6377             : 
    6378           6 :     if (read_backup_label(&checkPointLoc, &backupEndRequired,
    6379             :                           &backupFromStandby))
    6380             :     {
    6381           0 :         List       *tablespaces = NIL;
    6382             : 
    6383             :         /*
    6384             :          * Archive recovery was requested, and thanks to the backup label
    6385             :          * file, we know how far we need to replay to reach consistency. Enter
    6386             :          * archive recovery directly.
    6387             :          */
    6388           0 :         InArchiveRecovery = true;
    6389           0 :         if (StandbyModeRequested)
    6390           0 :             StandbyMode = true;
    6391             : 
    6392             :         /*

    6498             : 
    6499             :         /*
    6500             :          * It's possible that archive recovery was requested, but we don't
    6501             :          * know how far we need to replay the WAL before we reach consistency.
    6502             :          * This can happen for example if a base backup is taken from a
    6503             :          * running server using an atomic filesystem snapshot, without calling
    6504             :          * pg_start/stop_backup. Or if you just kill a running master server
    6505             :          * and put it into archive recovery by creating a recovery signal
    6506             :          * file.
    6507             :          *
    6508             :          * Our strategy in that case is to perform crash recovery first,
    6509             :          * replaying all the WAL present in pg_wal, and only enter archive
    6510             :          * recovery after that.
    6511             :          *
    6512             :          * But usually we already know how far we need to replay the WAL (up
    6513             :          * to minRecoveryPoint, up to backupEndPoint, or until we see an
    6514             :          * end-of-backup record), and we can enter archive recovery directly.
    6515             :          */

    6517           0 :             (ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint != InvalidXLogRecPtr ||

    6702             :      * server to a different archive than the master, it'd be good for all the
    6703             :      * history files to get archived there after failover, so that you can use

    6706             :      * regret later.

    6713             :      * taking any recovery action has the merit to discard any 2PC files that
    6714             :      * are newer than the first record to replay, saving from any conflicts at
    6715             :      * replay.  This avoids as well any subsequent scans when doing recovery

    6828             :          * if the instance crashes before the first post-recovery checkpoint
    6829             :          * is completed then recovery will use a stale location causing the
    6830             :          * startup process to think that there are still invalid page

    6852             :          * label file so that if we crash during recovery, we'll pick up at
    6853             :          * the latest recovery restartpoint instead of going all the way back
    6854             :          * to the backup start point.  It seems prudent though to just rename
    6855             :          * the file out of the way rather than delete it completely.
    6856             :          */
    6857           0 :         if (haveBackupLabel)
    6858             :         {
    6859           0 :             unlink(BACKUP_LABEL_OLD);
    6860           0 :             durable_rename(BACKUP_LABEL_FILE, BACKUP_LABEL_OLD, FATAL);
    6861             :         }

    6864             :          * If there was a tablespace_map file, it's done its job and the
    6865             :          * symlinks have been created.  We must get rid of the map file so
    6866             :          * that if we crash during recovery, we don't create symlinks again.
    6867             :          * It seems prudent though to just rename the file out of the way
    6868             :          * rather than delete it completely.

    6994             :          * crash.

    6996             :          * After this point, we can no longer assume that we're the only

    7317             :     /*

    7328             :      * completed successfully. Otherwise we'd not retry if any of the post

    7346           6 :     StandbyMode = false;

    7352           6 :     record = ReadRecord(xlogreader, LastRec, PANIC, false);

    7359             :      * and we were reading the old WAL from a segment belonging to a higher

    7362           6 :     EndOfLogTLI = xlogreader->seg.ws_tli;

    7365             :      * Complain if we did not roll forward far enough to render the backup
    7366             :      * dump consistent.  Note: it is indeed okay to look at the local variable
    7367             :      * minRecoveryPoint here, even though ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint might
    7368             :      * be further ahead --- ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint cannot have been
    7369             :      * advanced beyond the WAL we processed.
    7370             :      */
    7371           6 :     if (InRecovery &&
    7372           0 :         (EndOfLog < minRecoveryPoint ||
    7373           0 :          !XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(ControlFile->backupStartPoint)))
    7374             :     {
    7375             :         /*
    7376             :          * Ran off end of WAL before reaching end-of-backup WAL record, or
    7377             :          * minRecoveryPoint. That's usually a bad sign, indicating that you
    7378             :          * tried to recover from an online backup but never called
    7379             :          * pg_stop_backup(), or you didn't archive all the WAL up to that
    7380             :          * point. However, this also happens in crash recovery, if the system
    7381             :          * crashes while an online backup is in progress. We must not treat
    7382             :          * that as an error, or the database will refuse to start up.
    7383             :          */
    7384           0 :         if (ArchiveRecoveryRequested || ControlFile->backupEndRequired)
    7385             :         {
    7386           0 :             if (ControlFile->backupEndRequired)
    7387           0 :                 ereport(FATAL,
    7388             :                         (errmsg("WAL ends before end of online backup"),
    7389             :                          errhint("All WAL generated while online backup was taken must be available at recovery.")));
    7390           0 :             else if (!XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(ControlFile->backupStartPoint))
    7391           0 :                 ereport(FATAL,
    7392             :                         (errmsg("WAL ends before end of online backup"),
    7393             :                          errhint("Online backup started with pg_start_backup() must be ended with pg_stop_backup(), and all WAL up to that point must be available at recovery.")));
    7394             :             else
    7395           0 :                 ereport(FATAL,
    7396             :                         (errmsg("WAL ends before consistent recovery point")));
    7397             :         }
    7398             :     }
    7399             : 
    7400             :     /*
    7401             :      * Pre-scan prepared transactions to find out the range of XIDs present.
    7402             :      * This information is not quite needed yet, but it is positioned here so
    7403             :      * as potential problems are detected before any on-disk change is done.
    7404             :      */
    7405           6 :     oldestActiveXID = PrescanPreparedTransactions(NULL, NULL);
    7406             : 
    7407             :     /*
    7408             :      * Consider whether we need to assign a new timeline ID.
    7409             :      *
    7410             :      * If we are doing an archive recovery, we always assign a new ID.  This
    7411             :      * handles a couple of issues.  If we stopped short of the end of WAL
    7412             :      * during recovery, then we are clearly generating a new timeline and must
    7413             :      * assign it a unique new ID.  Even if we ran to the end, modifying the
    7414             :      * current last segment is problematic because it may result in trying to
    7415             :      * overwrite an already-archived copy of that segment, and we encourage
    7416             :      * DBAs to make their archive_commands reject that.  We can dodge the
    7417             :      * problem by making the new active segment have a new timeline ID.
    7418             :      *
    7419             :      * In a normal crash recovery, we can just extend the timeline we were in.
    7420             :      */
    7421           6 :     PrevTimeLineID = ThisTimeLineID;
    7422           6 :     if (ArchiveRecoveryRequested)
    7423             :     {
    7424             :         char        reason[200];
    7425             :         char        recoveryPath[MAXPGPATH];
    7426             : 
    7427           0 :         Assert(InArchiveRecovery);
    7428             : 
    7429           0 :         ThisTimeLineID = findNewestTimeLine(recoveryTargetTLI) + 1;
    7430           0 :         ereport(LOG,
    7431             :                 (errmsg("selected new timeline ID: %u", ThisTimeLineID)));
    7432             : 
    7433             :         /*
    7434             :          * Create a comment for the history file to explain why and where
    7435             :          * timeline changed.
    7436             :          */

    7438           0 :             snprintf(reason, sizeof(reason),

    7462             :         /*
    7463             :          * We are now done reading the old WAL.  Turn off archive fetching if

    7468           0 :         exitArchiveRecovery(EndOfLogTLI, EndOfLog);
    7469             : 
    7470             :         /*
    7471             :          * Write the timeline history file, and have it archived. After this
    7472             :          * point (or rather, as soon as the file is archived), the timeline
    7473             :          * will appear as "taken" in the WAL archive and to any standby
    7474             :          * servers.  If we crash before actually switching to the new
    7475             :          * timeline, standby servers will nevertheless think that we switched
    7476             :          * to the new timeline, and will try to connect to the new timeline.
    7477             :          * To minimize the window for that, try to do as little as possible
    7478             :          * between here and writing the end-of-recovery record.
    7479             :          */

    7486             :          */

    7488           0 :         unlink(recoveryPath);   /* ignore any error */
    7489             : 
    7490             :         /* Get rid of any remaining recovered timeline-history file, too */
    7491           0 :         snprintf(recoveryPath, MAXPGPATH, XLOGDIR "/RECOVERYHISTORY");
    7492           0 :         unlink(recoveryPath);   /* ignore any error */
    7493             :     }
    7494             :

    7557           6 :     LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed();

    7560             : 
    7561           6 :     if (InRecovery)
    7562             :     {
    7563             :         /*
    7564             :          * Perform a checkpoint to update all our recovery activity to disk.
    7565             :          *
    7566             :          * Note that we write a shutdown checkpoint rather than an on-line
    7567             :          * one. This is not particularly critical, but since we may be
    7568             :          * assigning a new TLI, using a shutdown checkpoint allows us to have
    7569             :          * the rule that TLI only changes in shutdown checkpoints, which
    7570             :          * allows some extra error checking in xlog_redo.
    7571             :          *
    7572             :          * In fast promotion, only create a lightweight end-of-recovery record
    7573             :          * instead of a full checkpoint. A checkpoint is requested later,
    7574             :          * after we're fully out of recovery mode and already accepting
    7575             :          * queries.
    7576             :          */
    7577           0 :         if (bgwriterLaunched)
    7578             :         {
    7579           0 :             if (fast_promote)
    7580             :             {
    7581           0 :                 checkPointLoc = ControlFile->checkPoint;
    7582             : 
    7583             :                 /*
    7584             :                  * Confirm the last checkpoint is available for us to recover
    7585             :                  * from if we fail.
    7586             :                  */
    7587           0 :                 record = ReadCheckpointRecord(xlogreader, checkPointLoc, 1, false);
    7588           0 :                 if (record != NULL)
    7589             :                 {
    7590           0 :                     fast_promoted = true;
    7591             : 
    7592             :                     /*
    7593             :                      * Insert a special WAL record to mark the end of
    7594             :                      * recovery, since we aren't doing a checkpoint. That
    7595             :                      * means that the checkpointer process may likely be in
    7596             :                      * the middle of a time-smoothed restartpoint and could
    7597             :                      * continue to be for minutes after this. That sounds
    7598             :                      * strange, but the effect is roughly the same and it
    7599             :                      * would be stranger to try to come out of the
    7600             :                      * restartpoint and then checkpoint. We request a
    7601             :                      * checkpoint later anyway, just for safety.
    7602             :                      */
    7603           0 :                     CreateEndOfRecoveryRecord();
    7604             :                 }
    7605             :             }
    7606             : 
    7607           0 :             if (!fast_promoted)
    7608           0 :                 RequestCheckpoint(CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY |
    7609             :                                   CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE |
    7610             :                                   CHECKPOINT_WAIT);
    7611             :         }
    7612             :         else
    7613           0 :             CreateCheckPoint(CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY | CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE);
    7614             :     }
    7615             : 
    7616           6 :     if (ArchiveRecoveryRequested)
    7617             :     {
    7618             :         /*
    7619             :          * And finally, execute the recovery_end_command, if any.
    7620             :          */

    7622           0 :             ExecuteRecoveryCommand(recoveryEndCommand,
    7623             :                                    "recovery_end_command",
    7624             :                                    true);
    7625             : 
    7626             :         /*
    7627             :          * We switched to a new timeline. Clean up segments on the old
    7628             :          * timeline.
    7629             :          *
    7630             :          * If there are any higher-numbered segments on the old timeline,
    7631             :          * remove them. They might contain valid WAL, but they might also be
    7632             :          * pre-allocated files containing garbage. In any case, they are not
    7633             :          * part of the new timeline's history so we don't need them.
    7634             :          */
    7635           0 :         RemoveNonParentXlogFiles(EndOfLog, ThisTimeLineID);
    7636             : 
    7637             :         /*
    7638             :          * If the switch happened in the middle of a segment, what to do with
    7639             :          * the last, partial segment on the old timeline? If we don't archive
    7640             :          * it, and the server that created the WAL never archives it either
    7641             :          * (e.g. because it was hit by a meteor), it will never make it to the
    7642             :          * archive. That's OK from our point of view, because the new segment
    7643             :          * that we created with the new TLI contains all the WAL from the old
    7644             :          * timeline up to the switch point. But if you later try to do PITR to
    7645             :          * the "missing" WAL on the old timeline, recovery won't find it in
    7646             :          * the archive. It's physically present in the new file with new TLI,
    7647             :          * but recovery won't look there when it's recovering to the older
    7648             :          * timeline. On the other hand, if we archive the partial segment, and
    7649             :          * the original server on that timeline is still running and archives
    7650             :          * the completed version of the same segment later, it will fail. (We
    7651             :          * used to do that in 9.4 and below, and it caused such problems).
    7652             :          *
    7653             :          * As a compromise, we rename the last segment with the .partial
    7654             :          * suffix, and archive it. Archive recovery will never try to read
    7655             :          * .partial segments, so they will normally go unused. But in the odd
    7656             :          * PITR case, the administrator can copy them manually to the pg_wal
    7657             :          * directory (removing the suffix). They can be useful in debugging,
    7658             :          * too.
    7659             :          *
    7660             :          * If a .done or .ready file already exists for the old timeline,
    7661             :          * however, we had already determined that the segment is complete, so
    7662             :          * we can let it be archived normally. (In particular, if it was
    7663             :          * restored from the archive to begin with, it's expected to have a
    7664             :          * .done file).
    7665             :          */
    7666           0 :         if (XLogSegmentOffset(EndOfLog, wal_segment_size) != 0 &&
    7667           0 :             XLogArchivingActive())
    7668             :         {
    7669             :             char        origfname[MAXFNAMELEN];

    7733             :     /* Reload shared-memory state for prepared transactions */

    7756           6 :     XLogReportParameters();
    7757             : 
    7758             :     /*
    7759             :      * Local WAL inserts enabled, so it's time to finish initialization of
    7760             :      * commit timestamp.
    7761             :      */
    7762           6 :     CompleteCommitTsInitialization();
    7763             : 
    7764             :     /*
    7765             :      * All done with end-of-recovery actions.
    7766             :      *
    7767             :      * Now allow backends to write WAL and update the control file status in
    7768             :      * consequence.  The boolean flag allowing backends to write WAL is
    7769             :      * updated while holding ControlFileLock to prevent other backends to look
    7770             :      * at an inconsistent state of the control file in shared memory.  There
    7771             :      * is still a small window during which backends can write WAL and the
    7772             :      * control file is still referring to a system not in DB_IN_PRODUCTION
    7773             :      * state while looking at the on-disk control file.
    7774             :      *
    7775             :      * Also, although the boolean flag to allow WAL is probably atomic in
    7776             :      * itself, we use the info_lck here to ensure that there are no race
    7777             :      * conditions concerning visibility of other recent updates to shared
    7778             :      * memory.
    7779             :      */
    7780           6 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    7781           6 :     ControlFile->state = DB_IN_PRODUCTION;
    7782           6 :     ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    7783             : 
    7784           6 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    7785           6 :     XLogCtl->SharedRecoveryInProgress = false;
    7786           6 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    7787             : 
    7788           6 :     UpdateControlFile();
    7789           6 :     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    7790             : 
    7791             :     /*
    7792             :      * If there were cascading standby servers connected to us, nudge any wal
    7793             :      * sender processes to notice that we've been promoted.
    7794             :      */
    7795           6 :     WalSndWakeup();
    7796             : 
    7797             :     /*
    7798             :      * If this was a fast promotion, request an (online) checkpoint now. This
    7799             :      * isn't required for consistency, but the last restartpoint might be far
    7800             :      * back, and in case of a crash, recovering from it might take a longer
    7801             :      * than is appropriate now that we're not in standby mode anymore.
    7802             :      */
    7803           6 :     if (fast_promoted)
    7804           0 :         RequestCheckpoint(CHECKPOINT_FORCE);
    7805           6 : }
    7806             : 
    7807             : /*
    7808             :  * Checks if recovery has reached a consistent state. When consistency is
    7809             :  * reached and we have a valid starting standby snapshot, tell postmaster
    7810             :  * that it can start accepting read-only connections.
    7811             :  */
    7812             : static void
    7813           0 : CheckRecoveryConsistency(void)
    7814             : {
    7815             :     XLogRecPtr  lastReplayedEndRecPtr;
    7816             : 
    7817             :     /*
    7818             :      * During crash recovery, we don't reach a consistent state until we've
    7819             :      * replayed all the WAL.
    7820             :      */
    7821           0 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(minRecoveryPoint))
    7822           0 :         return;
    7823             : 
    7824           0 :     Assert(InArchiveRecovery);
    7825             : 
    7826             :     /*
    7827             :      * assume that we are called in the startup process, and hence don't need
    7828             :      * a lock to read lastReplayedEndRecPtr
    7829             :      */
    7830           0 :     lastReplayedEndRecPtr = XLogCtl->lastReplayedEndRecPtr;
    7831             : 
    7832             :     /*
    7833             :      * Have we reached the point where our base backup was completed?
    7834             :      */
    7835           0 :     if (!XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(ControlFile->backupEndPoint) &&
    7836           0 :         ControlFile->backupEndPoint <= lastReplayedEndRecPtr)
    7837             :     {
    7838             :         /*
    7839             :          * We have reached the end of base backup, as indicated by pg_control.
    7840             :          * The data on disk is now consistent. Reset backupStartPoint and
    7841             :          * backupEndPoint, and update minRecoveryPoint to make sure we don't
    7842             :          * allow starting up at an earlier point even if recovery is stopped
    7843             :          * and restarted soon after this.
    7844             :          */
    7845           0 :         elog(DEBUG1, "end of backup reached");
    7846             :

    7904             : /*
    7905             :  * Is the system still in recovery?
    7906             :  *

    8221             : /*

    8225             :  * xlog page. It lags behind the real insert position by at most 1 page.

    8391             :     uint64      average_sync_time;
    8392             : 
    8393          22 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_end_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    8394             : 
    8395          22 :     TimestampDifference(CheckpointStats.ckpt_write_t,
    8396             :                         CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_t,
    8397             :                         &write_secs, &write_usecs);
    8398             : 
    8399          22 :     TimestampDifference(CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_t,
    8400             :                         CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_end_t,
    8401             :                         &sync_secs, &sync_usecs);
    8402             : 
    8403             :     /* Accumulate checkpoint timing summary data, in milliseconds. */
    8404          44 :     BgWriterStats.m_checkpoint_write_time +=
    8405          22 :         write_secs * 1000 + write_usecs / 1000;
    8406          44 :     BgWriterStats.m_checkpoint_sync_time +=
    8407          22 :         sync_secs * 1000 + sync_usecs / 1000;
    8408             : 
    8409             :     /*
    8410             :      * All of the published timing statistics are accounted for.  Only
    8411             :      * continue if a log message is to be written.
    8412             :      */
    8413          22 :     if (!log_checkpoints)
    8414          34 :         return;
    8415             : 
    8416          10 :     TimestampDifference(CheckpointStats.ckpt_start_t,
    8417             :                         CheckpointStats.ckpt_end_t,
    8418             :                         &total_secs, &total_usecs);
    8419             : 
    8420             :     /*
    8421             :      * Timing values returned from CheckpointStats are in microseconds.
    8422             :      * Convert to the second plus microsecond form that TimestampDifference
    8423             :      * returns for homogeneous printing.
    8424             :      */
    8425          10 :     longest_secs = (long) (CheckpointStats.ckpt_longest_sync / 1000000);
    8426          10 :     longest_usecs = CheckpointStats.ckpt_longest_sync -
    8427             :         (uint64) longest_secs * 1000000;
    8428             : 
    8429          10 :     average_sync_time = 0;
    8430          10 :     if (CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_rels > 0)
    8431           0 :         average_sync_time = CheckpointStats.ckpt_agg_sync_time /
    8432           0 :             CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_rels;
    8433          10 :     average_secs = (long) (average_sync_time / 1000000);
    8434          10 :     average_usecs = average_sync_time - (uint64) average_secs * 1000000;
    8435             : 
    8436          10 :     elog(LOG, "%s complete: wrote %d buffers (%.1f%%); "
    8437             :          "%d WAL file(s) added, %d removed, %d recycled; "
    8438             :          "write=%ld.%03d s, sync=%ld.%03d s, total=%ld.%03d s; "
    8439             :          "sync files=%d, longest=%ld.%03d s, average=%ld.%03d s; "
    8440             :          "distance=%d kB, estimate=%d kB",
    8441             :          restartpoint ? "restartpoint" : "checkpoint",
    8442             :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_bufs_written,
    8443             :          (double) CheckpointStats.ckpt_bufs_written * 100 / NBuffers,
    8444             :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_added,
    8445             :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_removed,
    8446             :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_recycled,
    8447             :          write_secs, write_usecs / 1000,
    8448             :          sync_secs, sync_usecs / 1000,
    8449             :          total_secs, total_usecs / 1000,
    8450             :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_rels,
    8451             :          longest_secs, longest_usecs / 1000,
    8452             :          average_secs, average_usecs / 1000,
    8453             :          (int) (PrevCheckPointDistance / 1024.0),
    8454             :          (int) (CheckPointDistanceEstimate / 1024.0));
    8455             : }
    8456             : 
    8457             : /*
    8458             :  * Update the estimate of distance between checkpoints.
    8459             :  *
    8460             :  * The estimate is used to calculate the number of WAL segments to keep
    8461             :  * preallocated, see XLOGfileslop().
    8462             :  */
    8463             : static void
    8464          22 : UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate(uint64 nbytes)
    8465             : {
    8466             :     /*
    8467             :      * To estimate the number of segments consumed between checkpoints, keep a
    8468             :      * moving average of the amount of WAL generated in previous checkpoint
    8469             :      * cycles. However, if the load is bursty, with quiet periods and busy
    8470             :      * periods, we want to cater for the peak load. So instead of a plain
    8471             :      * moving average, let the average decline slowly if the previous cycle
    8472             :      * used less WAL than estimated, but bump it up immediately if it used
    8473             :      * more.
    8474             :      *
    8475             :      * When checkpoints are triggered by max_wal_size, this should converge to
    8476             :      * CheckpointSegments * wal_segment_size,
    8477             :      *
    8478             :      * Note: This doesn't pay any attention to what caused the checkpoint.
    8479             :      * Checkpoints triggered manually with CHECKPOINT command, or by e.g.
    8480             :      * starting a base backup, are counted the same as those created
    8481             :      * automatically. The slow-decline will largely mask them out, if they are
    8482             :      * not frequent. If they are frequent, it seems reasonable to count them
    8483             :      * in as any others; if you issue a manual checkpoint every 5 minutes and
    8484             :      * never let a timed checkpoint happen, it makes sense to base the
    8485             :      * preallocation on that 5 minute interval rather than whatever
    8486             :      * checkpoint_timeout is set to.
    8487             :      */
    8488          22 :     PrevCheckPointDistance = nbytes;
    8489          22 :     if (CheckPointDistanceEstimate < nbytes)
    8490          10 :         CheckPointDistanceEstimate = nbytes;
    8491             :     else
    8492          12 :         CheckPointDistanceEstimate =
    8493          12 :             (0.90 * CheckPointDistanceEstimate + 0.10 * (double) nbytes);
    8494          22 : }
    8495             : 
    8496             : /*
    8497             :  * Perform a checkpoint --- either during shutdown, or on-the-fly
    8498             :  *
    8499             :  * flags is a bitwise OR of the following:
    8500             :  *  CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN: checkpoint is for database shutdown.
    8501             :  *  CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY: checkpoint is for end of WAL recovery.
    8502             :  *  CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE: finish the checkpoint ASAP,
    8503             :  *      ignoring checkpoint_completion_target parameter.
    8504             :  *  CHECKPOINT_FORCE: force a checkpoint even if no XLOG activity has occurred
    8505             :  *      since the last one (implied by CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN or
    8506             :  *      CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY).
    8507             :  *  CHECKPOINT_FLUSH_ALL: also flush buffers of unlogged tables.
    8508             :  *
    8509             :  * Note: flags contains other bits, of interest here only for logging purposes.
    8510             :  * In particular note that this routine is synchronous and does not pay
    8511             :  * attention to CHECKPOINT_WAIT.
    8512             :  *
    8513             :  * If !shutdown then we are writing an online checkpoint. This is a very special
    8514             :  * kind of operation and WAL record because the checkpoint action occurs over
    8515             :  * a period of time yet logically occurs at just a single LSN. The logical
    8516             :  * position of the WAL record (redo ptr) is the same or earlier than the
    8517             :  * physical position. When we replay WAL we locate the checkpoint via its
    8518             :  * physical position then read the redo ptr and actually start replay at the
    8519             :  * earlier logical position. Note that we don't write *anything* to WAL at
    8520             :  * the logical position, so that location could be any other kind of WAL record.
    8521             :  * All of this mechanism allows us to continue working while we checkpoint.
    8522             :  * As a result, timing of actions is critical here and be careful to note that
    8523             :  * this function will likely take minutes to execute on a busy system.
    8524             :  */
    8525             : void
    8526          22 : CreateCheckPoint(int flags)
    8527             : {
    8528             :     bool        shutdown;
    8529             :     CheckPoint  checkPoint;
    8530             :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    8531             :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
    8532          22 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    8533             :     uint32      freespace;
    8534             :     XLogRecPtr  PriorRedoPtr;
    8535             :     XLogRecPtr  curInsert;
    8536             :     XLogRecPtr  last_important_lsn;
    8537             :     VirtualTransactionId *vxids;
    8538             :     int         nvxids;
    8539             : 
    8540             :     /*
    8541             :      * An end-of-recovery checkpoint is really a shutdown checkpoint, just
    8542             :      * issued at a different time.
    8543             :      */
    8544          22 :     if (flags & (CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN | CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY))
    8545           6 :         shutdown = true;
    8546             :     else
    8547          16 :         shutdown = false;
    8548             : 
    8549             :     /* sanity check */
    8550          22 :     if (RecoveryInProgress() && (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY) == 0)
    8551           0 :         elog(ERROR, "can't create a checkpoint during recovery");
    8552             : 
    8553             :     /*
    8554             :      * Initialize InitXLogInsert working areas before entering the critical
    8555             :      * section.  Normally, this is done by the first call to
    8556             :      * RecoveryInProgress() or LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed(), but when creating
    8557             :      * an end-of-recovery checkpoint, the LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed call is
    8558             :      * done below in a critical section, and InitXLogInsert cannot be called
    8559             :      * in a critical section.
    8560             :      */
    8561          22 :     InitXLogInsert();
    8562             : 
    8563             :     /*
    8564             :      * Acquire CheckpointLock to ensure only one checkpoint happens at a time.
    8565             :      * (This is just pro forma, since in the present system structure there is
    8566             :      * only one process that is allowed to issue checkpoints at any given
    8567             :      * time.)
    8568             :      */
    8569          22 :     LWLockAcquire(CheckpointLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    8570             : 
    8571             :     /*
    8572             :      * Prepare to accumulate statistics.
    8573             :      *
    8574             :      * Note: because it is possible for log_checkpoints to change while a
    8575             :      * checkpoint proceeds, we always accumulate stats, even if
    8576             :      * log_checkpoints is currently off.
    8577             :      */
    8578          22 :     MemSet(&CheckpointStats, 0, sizeof(CheckpointStats));
    8579          22 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_start_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    8580             : 
    8581             :     /*
    8582             :      * Use a critical section to force system panic if we have trouble.
    8583             :      */
    8584          22 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    8585             : 
    8586          22 :     if (shutdown)
    8587             :     {
    8588           6 :         LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    8589           6 :         ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNING;
    8590           6 :         ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    8591           6 :         UpdateControlFile();
    8592           6 :         LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    8593             :     }
    8594             : 
    8595             :     /*
    8596             :      * Let smgr prepare for checkpoint; this has to happen before we determine
    8597             :      * the REDO pointer.  Note that smgr must not do anything that'd have to
    8598             :      * be undone if we decide no checkpoint is needed.
    8599             :      */
    8600          22 :     SyncPreCheckpoint();
    8601             : 
    8602             :     /* Begin filling in the checkpoint WAL record */
    8603          22 :     MemSet(&checkPoint, 0, sizeof(checkPoint));
    8604          22 :     checkPoint.time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    8605             : 
    8606             :     /*
    8607             :      * For Hot Standby, derive the oldestActiveXid before we fix the redo
    8608             :      * pointer. This allows us to begin accumulating changes to assemble our
    8609             :      * starting snapshot of locks and transactions.
    8610             :      */
    8611          22 :     if (!shutdown && XLogStandbyInfoActive())
    8612          16 :         checkPoint.oldestActiveXid = GetOldestActiveTransactionId();
    8613             :     else
    8614           6 :         checkPoint.oldestActiveXid = InvalidTransactionId;
    8615             : 
    8616             :     /*
    8617             :      * Get location of last important record before acquiring insert locks (as
    8618             :      * GetLastImportantRecPtr() also locks WAL locks).
    8619             :      */
    8620          22 :     last_important_lsn = GetLastImportantRecPtr();
    8621             : 
    8622             :     /*
    8623             :      * We must block concurrent insertions while examining insert state to
    8624             :      * determine the checkpoint REDO pointer.
    8625             :      */
    8626          22 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    8627          22 :     curInsert = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(Insert->CurrBytePos);
    8628             : 
    8629             :     /*
    8630             :      * If this isn't a shutdown or forced checkpoint, and if there has been no
    8631             :      * WAL activity requiring a checkpoint, skip it.  The idea here is to
    8632             :      * avoid inserting duplicate checkpoints when the system is idle.
    8633             :      */
    8634          22 :     if ((flags & (CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN | CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY |
    8635             :                   CHECKPOINT_FORCE)) == 0)
    8636             :     {
    8637           0 :         if (last_important_lsn == ControlFile->checkPoint)
    8638             :         {
    8639           0 :             WALInsertLockRelease();
    8640           0 :             LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    8641           0 :             END_CRIT_SECTION();
    8642           0 :             ereport(DEBUG1,
    8643             :                     (errmsg("checkpoint skipped because system is idle")));
    8644          22 :             return;
    8645             :         }
    8646             :     }
    8647             : 
    8648             :     /*
    8649             :      * An end-of-recovery checkpoint is created before anyone is allowed to
    8650             :      * write WAL. To allow us to write the checkpoint record, temporarily
    8651             :      * enable XLogInsertAllowed.  (This also ensures ThisTimeLineID is
    8652             :      * initialized, which we need here and in AdvanceXLInsertBuffer.)
    8653             :      */
    8654          22 :     if (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY)
    8655           0 :         LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed();
    8656             : 
    8657          22 :     checkPoint.ThisTimeLineID = ThisTimeLineID;
    8658          22 :     if (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY)
    8659           0 :         checkPoint.PrevTimeLineID = XLogCtl->PrevTimeLineID;
    8660             :     else
    8661          22 :         checkPoint.PrevTimeLineID = ThisTimeLineID;
    8662             : 
    8663          22 :     checkPoint.fullPageWrites = Insert->fullPageWrites;
    8664             : 
    8665             :     /*
    8666             :      * Compute new REDO record ptr = location of next XLOG record.
    8667             :      *
    8668             :      * NB: this is NOT necessarily where the checkpoint record itself will be,
    8669             :      * since other backends may insert more XLOG records while we're off doing
    8670             :      * the buffer flush work.  Those XLOG records are logically after the
    8671             :      * checkpoint, even though physically before it.  Got that?
    8672             :      */
    8673          22 :     freespace = INSERT_FREESPACE(curInsert);
    8674          22 :     if (freespace == 0)
    8675             :     {
    8676           0 :         if (XLogSegmentOffset(curInsert, wal_segment_size) == 0)
    8677           0 :             curInsert += SizeOfXLogLongPHD;
    8678             :         else
    8679           0 :             curInsert += SizeOfXLogShortPHD;
    8680             :     }
    8681          22 :     checkPoint.redo = curInsert;
    8682             : 
    8683             :     /*
    8684             :      * Here we update the shared RedoRecPtr for future XLogInsert calls; this
    8685             :      * must be done while holding all the insertion locks.
    8686             :      *
    8687             :      * Note: if we fail to complete the checkpoint, RedoRecPtr will be left
    8688             :      * pointing past where it really needs to point.  This is okay; the only
    8689             :      * consequence is that XLogInsert might back up whole buffers that it
    8690             :      * didn't really need to.  We can't postpone advancing RedoRecPtr because
    8691             :      * XLogInserts that happen while we are dumping buffers must assume that
    8692             :      * their buffer changes are not included in the checkpoint.
    8693             :      */
    8694          22 :     RedoRecPtr = XLogCtl->Insert.RedoRecPtr = checkPoint.redo;
    8695             : 
    8696             :     /*
    8697             :      * Now we can release the WAL insertion locks, allowing other xacts to
    8698             :      * proceed while we are flushing disk buffers.
    8699             :      */
    8700          22 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    8701             : 
    8702             :     /* Update the info_lck-protected copy of RedoRecPtr as well */
    8703          22 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8704          22 :     XLogCtl->RedoRecPtr = checkPoint.redo;
    8705          22 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8706             : 
    8707             :     /*
    8708             :      * If enabled, log checkpoint start.  We postpone this until now so as not
    8709             :      * to log anything if we decided to skip the checkpoint.
    8710             :      */
    8711          22 :     if (log_checkpoints)
    8712          10 :         LogCheckpointStart(flags, false);
    8713             : 
    8714             :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_CHECKPOINT_START(flags);
    8715             : 
    8716             :     /*
    8717             :      * Get the other info we need for the checkpoint record.
    8718             :      *
    8719             :      * We don't need to save oldestClogXid in the checkpoint, it only matters
    8720             :      * for the short period in which clog is being truncated, and if we crash
    8721             :      * during that we'll redo the clog truncation and fix up oldestClogXid
    8722             :      * there.
    8723             :      */
    8724          22 :     LWLockAcquire(XidGenLock, LW_SHARED);
    8725          22 :     checkPoint.nextFullXid = ShmemVariableCache->nextFullXid;
    8726          22 :     checkPoint.oldestXid = ShmemVariableCache->oldestXid;
    8727          22 :     checkPoint.oldestXidDB = ShmemVariableCache->oldestXidDB;
    8728          22 :     LWLockRelease(XidGenLock);
    8729             : 
    8730          22 :     LWLockAcquire(CommitTsLock, LW_SHARED);
    8731          22 :     checkPoint.oldestCommitTsXid = ShmemVariableCache->oldestCommitTsXid;
    8732          22 :     checkPoint.newestCommitTsXid = ShmemVariableCache->newestCommitTsXid;
    8733          22 :     LWLockRelease(CommitTsLock);
    8734             : 
    8735          22 :     LWLockAcquire(OidGenLock, LW_SHARED);
    8736          22 :     checkPoint.nextOid = ShmemVariableCache->nextOid;
    8737          22 :     if (!shutdown)
    8738          16 :         checkPoint.nextOid += ShmemVariableCache->oidCount;
    8739          22 :     LWLockRelease(OidGenLock);
    8740             : 
    8741          22 :     MultiXactGetCheckptMulti(shutdown,
    8742             :                              &checkPoint.nextMulti,
    8743             :                              &checkPoint.nextMultiOffset,
    8744             :                              &checkPoint.oldestMulti,
    8745             :                              &checkPoint.oldestMultiDB);
    8746             : 
    8747             :     /*
    8748             :      * Having constructed the checkpoint record, ensure all shmem disk buffers
    8749             :      * and commit-log buffers are flushed to disk.
    8750             :      *
    8751             :      * This I/O could fail for various reasons.  If so, we will fail to
    8752             :      * complete the checkpoint, but there is no reason to force a system
    8753             :      * panic. Accordingly, exit critical section while doing it.
    8754             :      */
    8755          22 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    8756             : 
    8757             :     /*
    8758             :      * In some cases there are groups of actions that must all occur on one
    8759             :      * side or the other of a checkpoint record. Before flushing the
    8760             :      * checkpoint record we must explicitly wait for any backend currently
    8761             :      * performing those groups of actions.
    8762             :      *
    8763             :      * One example is end of transaction, so we must wait for any transactions
    8764             :      * that are currently in commit critical sections.  If an xact inserted
    8765             :      * its commit record into XLOG just before the REDO point, then a crash
    8766             :      * restart from the REDO point would not replay that record, which means
    8767             :      * that our flushing had better include the xact's update of pg_xact.  So
    8768             :      * we wait till he's out of his commit critical section before proceeding.
    8769             :      * See notes in RecordTransactionCommit().
    8770             :      *
    8771             :      * Because we've already released the insertion locks, this test is a bit
    8772             :      * fuzzy: it is possible that we will wait for xacts we didn't really need
    8773             :      * to wait for.  But the delay should be short and it seems better to make
    8774             :      * checkpoint take a bit longer than to hold off insertions longer than
    8775             :      * necessary. (In fact, the whole reason we have this issue is that xact.c
    8776             :      * does commit record XLOG insertion and clog update as two separate steps
    8777             :      * protected by different locks, but again that seems best on grounds of
    8778             :      * minimizing lock contention.)
    8779             :      *
    8780             :      * A transaction that has not yet set delayChkpt when we look cannot be at
    8781             :      * risk, since he's not inserted his commit record yet; and one that's
    8782             :      * already cleared it is not at risk either, since he's done fixing clog
    8783             :      * and we will correctly flush the update below.  So we cannot miss any
    8784             :      * xacts we need to wait for.
    8785             :      */
    8786          22 :     vxids = GetVirtualXIDsDelayingChkpt(&nvxids);
    8787          22 :     if (nvxids > 0)
    8788             :     {
    8789             :         do
    8790             :         {
    8791           0 :             pg_usleep(10000L);  /* wait for 10 msec */
    8792           0 :         } while (HaveVirtualXIDsDelayingChkpt(vxids, nvxids));
    8793             :     }
    8794          22 :     pfree(vxids);
    8795             : 
    8796          22 :     CheckPointGuts(checkPoint.redo, flags);
    8797             : 
    8798             :     /*
    8799             :      * Take a snapshot of running transactions and write this to WAL. This
    8800             :      * allows us to reconstruct the state of running transactions during
    8801             :      * archive recovery, if required. Skip, if this info disabled.
    8802             :      *
    8803             :      * If we are shutting down, or Startup process is completing crash
    8804             :      * recovery we don't need to write running xact data.
    8805             :      */
    8806          22 :     if (!shutdown && XLogStandbyInfoActive())
    8807          16 :         LogStandbySnapshot();
    8808             : 
    8809          22 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    8810             : 
    8811             :     /*
    8812             :      * Now insert the checkpoint record into XLOG.
    8813             :      */
    8814          22 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    8815          22 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) (&checkPoint), sizeof(checkPoint));
    8816          22 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID,
    8817             :                         shutdown ? XLOG_CHECKPOINT_SHUTDOWN :
    8818             :                         XLOG_CHECKPOINT_ONLINE);
    8819             : 
    8820          22 :     XLogFlush(recptr);
    8821             : 
    8822             :     /*
    8823             :      * We mustn't write any new WAL after a shutdown checkpoint, or it will be
    8824             :      * overwritten at next startup.  No-one should even try, this just allows
    8825             :      * sanity-checking.  In the case of an end-of-recovery checkpoint, we want
    8826             :      * to just temporarily disable writing until the system has exited
    8827             :      * recovery.
    8828             :      */
    8829          22 :     if (shutdown)
    8830             :     {
    8831           6 :         if (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY)
    8832           0 :             LocalXLogInsertAllowed = -1;    /* return to "check" state */
    8833             :         else
    8834           6 :             LocalXLogInsertAllowed = 0; /* never again write WAL */
    8835             :     }
    8836             : 
    8837             :     /*
    8838             :      * We now have ProcLastRecPtr = start of actual checkpoint record, recptr
    8839             :      * = end of actual checkpoint record.
    8840             :      */
    8841          22 :     if (shutdown && checkPoint.redo != ProcLastRecPtr)
    8842           0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    8843             :                 (errmsg("concurrent write-ahead log activity while database system is shutting down")));
    8844             : 
    8845             :     /*
    8846             :      * Remember the prior checkpoint's redo ptr for
    8847             :      * UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate()
    8848             :      */
    8849          22 :     PriorRedoPtr = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo;
    8850             : 
    8851             :     /*
    8852             :      * Update the control file.
    8853             :      */
    8854          22 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    8855          22 :     if (shutdown)
    8856           6 :         ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNED;
    8857          22 :     ControlFile->checkPoint = ProcLastRecPtr;
    8858          22 :     ControlFile->checkPointCopy = checkPoint;
    8859          22 :     ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    8860             :     /* crash recovery should always recover to the end of WAL */
    8861          22 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    8862          22 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI = 0;
    8863             : 
    8864             :     /*
    8865             :      * Persist unloggedLSN value. It's reset on crash recovery, so this goes
    8866             :      * unused on non-shutdown checkpoints, but seems useful to store it always
    8867             :      * for debugging purposes.
    8868             :      */
    8869          22 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->ulsn_lck);
    8870          22 :     ControlFile->unloggedLSN = XLogCtl->unloggedLSN;
    8871          22 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->ulsn_lck);
    8872             : 
    8873          22 :     UpdateControlFile();
    8874          22 :     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    8875             : 
    8876             :     /* Update shared-memory copy of checkpoint XID/epoch */
    8877          22 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8878          22 :     XLogCtl->ckptFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    8879          22 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8880             : 
    8881             :     /*
    8882             :      * We are now done with critical updates; no need for system panic if we
    8883             :      * have trouble while fooling with old log segments.
    8884             :      */
    8885          22 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    8886             : 
    8887             :     /*
    8888             :      * Let smgr do post-checkpoint cleanup (eg, deleting old files).
    8889             :      */
    8890          22 :     SyncPostCheckpoint();
    8891             : 
    8892             :     /*
    8893             :      * Update the average distance between checkpoints if the prior checkpoint
    8894             :      * exists.
    8895             :      */
    8896          22 :     if (PriorRedoPtr != InvalidXLogRecPtr)
    8897          22 :         UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate(RedoRecPtr - PriorRedoPtr);
    8898             : 
    8899             :     /*
    8900             :      * Delete old log files, those no longer needed for last checkpoint to
    8901             :      * prevent the disk holding the xlog from growing full.
    8902             :      */
    8903          22 :     XLByteToSeg(RedoRecPtr, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    8904          22 :     KeepLogSeg(recptr, &_logSegNo);
    8905          22 :     _logSegNo--;
    8906          22 :     RemoveOldXlogFiles(_logSegNo, RedoRecPtr, recptr);
    8907             : 
    8908             :     /*
    8909             :      * Make more log segments if needed.  (Do this after recycling old log
    8910             :      * segments, since that may supply some of the needed files.)
    8911             :      */
    8912          22 :     if (!shutdown)
    8913          16 :         PreallocXlogFiles(recptr);
    8914             : 
    8915             :     /*
    8916             :      * Truncate pg_subtrans if possible.  We can throw away all data before
    8917             :      * the oldest XMIN of any running transaction.  No future transaction will
    8918             :      * attempt to reference any pg_subtrans entry older than that (see Asserts
    8919             :      * in subtrans.c).  During recovery, though, we mustn't do this because
    8920             :      * StartupSUBTRANS hasn't been called yet.
    8921             :      */
    8922          22 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    8923          22 :         TruncateSUBTRANS(GetOldestXmin(NULL, PROCARRAY_FLAGS_DEFAULT));
    8924             : 
    8925             :     /* Real work is done, but log and update stats before releasing lock. */
    8926          22 :     LogCheckpointEnd(false);
    8927             : 
    8928             :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_CHECKPOINT_DONE(CheckpointStats.ckpt_bufs_written,
    8929             :                                      NBuffers,
    8930             :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_added,
    8931             :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_removed,
    8932             :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_recycled);
    8933             : 
    8934          22 :     LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    8935             : }
    8936             : 
    8937             : /*
    8938             :  * Mark the end of recovery in WAL though without running a full checkpoint.
    8939             :  * We can expect that a restartpoint is likely to be in progress as we
    8940             :  * do this, though we are unwilling to wait for it to complete. So be
    8941             :  * careful to avoid taking the CheckpointLock anywhere here.
    8942             :  *
    8943             :  * CreateRestartPoint() allows for the case where recovery may end before
    8944             :  * the restartpoint completes so there is no concern of concurrent behaviour.
    8945             :  */
    8946             : static void
    8947           0 : CreateEndOfRecoveryRecord(void)
    8948             : {
    8949             :     xl_end_of_recovery xlrec;
    8950             :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    8951             : 
    8952             :     /* sanity check */
    8953           0 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    8954           0 :         elog(ERROR, "can only be used to end recovery");
    8955             : 
    8956           0 :     xlrec.end_time = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    8957             : 
    8958           0 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    8959           0 :     xlrec.ThisTimeLineID = ThisTimeLineID;
    8960           0 :     xlrec.PrevTimeLineID = XLogCtl->PrevTimeLineID;
    8961           0 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    8962             : 
    8963           0 :     LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed();
    8964             : 
    8965           0 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    8966             : 
    8967           0 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    8968           0 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, sizeof(xl_end_of_recovery));
    8969           0 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_END_OF_RECOVERY);
    8970             : 
    8971           0 :     XLogFlush(recptr);
    8972             : 
    8973             :     /*
    8974             :      * Update the control file so that crash recovery can follow the timeline
    8975             :      * changes to this point.
    8976             :      */
    8977           0 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    8978           0 :     ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    8979           0 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint = recptr;
    8980           0 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI = ThisTimeLineID;
    8981           0 :     UpdateControlFile();
    8982           0 :     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    8983             : 
    8984           0 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    8985             : 
    8986           0 :     LocalXLogInsertAllowed = -1;    /* return to "check" state */
    8987           0 : }
    8988             : 
    8989             : /*
    8990             :  * Flush all data in shared memory to disk, and fsync
    8991             :  *
    8992             :  * This is the common code shared between regular checkpoints and
    8993             :  * recovery restartpoints.
    8994             :  */
    8995             : static void
    8996          22 : CheckPointGuts(XLogRecPtr checkPointRedo, int flags)
    8997             : {
    8998          22 :     CheckPointCLOG();
