    9000          22 :     CheckPointSUBTRANS();
    9001          22 :     CheckPointMultiXact();
    9002          22 :     CheckPointPredicate();
    9003          22 :     CheckPointRelationMap();
    9004          22 :     CheckPointReplicationSlots();
    9005          22 :     CheckPointSnapBuild();
    9006          22 :     CheckPointLogicalRewriteHeap();
    9007          22 :     CheckPointBuffers(flags);   /* performs all required fsyncs */
    9008          22 :     CheckPointReplicationOrigin();
    9009             :     /* We deliberately delay 2PC checkpointing as long as possible */
    9010          22 :     CheckPointTwoPhase(checkPointRedo);
    9011          22 : }
    9012             : 
    9013             : /*
    9014             :  * Save a checkpoint for recovery restart if appropriate
    9015             :  *
    9016             :  * This function is called each time a checkpoint record is read from XLOG.
    9017             :  * It must determine whether the checkpoint represents a safe restartpoint or
    9018             :  * not.  If so, the checkpoint record is stashed in shared memory so that
    9019             :  * CreateRestartPoint can consult it.  (Note that the latter function is
    9020             :  * executed by the checkpointer, while this one will be executed by the
    9021             :  * startup process.)
    9022             :  */
    9023             : static void
    9024           0 : RecoveryRestartPoint(const CheckPoint *checkPoint)
    9025             : {
    9026             :     /*
    9027             :      * Also refrain from creating a restartpoint if we have seen any
    9028             :      * references to non-existent pages. Restarting recovery from the
    9029             :      * restartpoint would not see the references, so we would lose the
    9030             :      * cross-check that the pages belonged to a relation that was dropped
    9031             :      * later.
    9032             :      */
    9033           0 :     if (XLogHaveInvalidPages())
    9034             :     {
    9035           0 :         elog(trace_recovery(DEBUG2),
    9036             :              "could not record restart point at %X/%X because there "
    9037             :              "are unresolved references to invalid pages",
    9038             :              (uint32) (checkPoint->redo >> 32),
    9039             :              (uint32) checkPoint->redo);
    9040           0 :         return;
    9041             :     }
    9042             : 
    9043             :     /*
    9044             :      * Copy the checkpoint record to shared memory, so that checkpointer can
    9045             :      * work out the next time it wants to perform a restartpoint.
    9046             :      */
    9047           0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9048           0 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPointRecPtr = ReadRecPtr;
    9049           0 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPointEndPtr = EndRecPtr;
    9050           0 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPoint = *checkPoint;
    9051           0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9052             : }
    9053             : 
    9054             : /*
    9055             :  * Establish a restartpoint if possible.
    9056             :  *
    9057             :  * This is similar to CreateCheckPoint, but is used during WAL recovery
    9058             :  * to establish a point from which recovery can roll forward without
    9059             :  * replaying the entire recovery log.
    9060             :  *
    9061             :  * Returns true if a new restartpoint was established. We can only establish
    9062             :  * a restartpoint if we have replayed a safe checkpoint record since last
    9063             :  * restartpoint.
    9064             :  */
    9065             : bool
    9066           0 : CreateRestartPoint(int flags)
    9067             : {
    9068             :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointRecPtr;
    9069             :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointEndPtr;
    9070             :     CheckPoint  lastCheckPoint;
    9071             :     XLogRecPtr  PriorRedoPtr;
    9072             :     XLogRecPtr  receivePtr;
    9073             :     XLogRecPtr  replayPtr;
    9074             :     TimeLineID  replayTLI;
    9075             :     XLogRecPtr  endptr;
    9076             :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
    9077             :     TimestampTz xtime;
    9078             : 
    9079             :     /*
    9080             :      * Acquire CheckpointLock to ensure only one restartpoint or checkpoint
    9081             :      * happens at a time.
    9082             :      */
    9083           0 :     LWLockAcquire(CheckpointLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9084             : 
    9085             :     /* Get a local copy of the last safe checkpoint record. */
    9086           0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9087           0 :     lastCheckPointRecPtr = XLogCtl->lastCheckPointRecPtr;
    9088           0 :     lastCheckPointEndPtr = XLogCtl->lastCheckPointEndPtr;
    9089           0 :     lastCheckPoint = XLogCtl->lastCheckPoint;
    9090           0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9091             : 
    9092             :     /*
    9093             :      * Check that we're still in recovery mode. It's ok if we exit recovery
    9094             :      * mode after this check, the restart point is valid anyway.
    9095             :      */
    9096           0 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    9097             :     {
    9098           0 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    9099             :                 (errmsg("skipping restartpoint, recovery has already ended")));
    9100           0 :         LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    9101           0 :         return false;
    9102             :     }
    9103             : 
    9104             :     /*
    9105             :      * If the last checkpoint record we've replayed is already our last
    9106             :      * restartpoint, we can't perform a new restart point. We still update
    9107             :      * minRecoveryPoint in that case, so that if this is a shutdown restart
    9108             :      * point, we won't start up earlier than before. That's not strictly
    9109             :      * necessary, but when hot standby is enabled, it would be rather weird if
    9110             :      * the database opened up for read-only connections at a point-in-time
    9111             :      * before the last shutdown. Such time travel is still possible in case of
    9112             :      * immediate shutdown, though.
    9113             :      *
    9114             :      * We don't explicitly advance minRecoveryPoint when we do create a
    9115             :      * restartpoint. It's assumed that flushing the buffers will do that as a
    9116             :      * side-effect.
    9117             :      */
    9118           0 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(lastCheckPointRecPtr) ||
    9119           0 :         lastCheckPoint.redo <= ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo)
    9120             :     {
    9121           0 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    9122             :                 (errmsg("skipping restartpoint, already performed at %X/%X",
    9123             :                         (uint32) (lastCheckPoint.redo >> 32),
    9124             :                         (uint32) lastCheckPoint.redo)));
    9125             : 
    9126           0 :         UpdateMinRecoveryPoint(InvalidXLogRecPtr, true);
    9127           0 :         if (flags & CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN)
    9128             :         {
    9129           0 :             LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9130           0 :             ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNED_IN_RECOVERY;
    9131           0 :             ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    9132           0 :             UpdateControlFile();
    9133           0 :             LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9134             :         }
    9135           0 :         LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    9136           0 :         return false;
    9137             :     }
    9138             : 
    9139             :     /*
    9140             :      * Update the shared RedoRecPtr so that the startup process can calculate
    9141             :      * the number of segments replayed since last restartpoint, and request a
    9142             :      * restartpoint if it exceeds CheckPointSegments.
    9143             :      *
    9144             :      * Like in CreateCheckPoint(), hold off insertions to update it, although
    9145             :      * during recovery this is just pro forma, because no WAL insertions are
    9146             :      * happening.
    9147             :      */
    9148           0 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9149           0 :     RedoRecPtr = XLogCtl->Insert.RedoRecPtr = lastCheckPoint.redo;
    9150           0 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    9151             : 
    9152             :     /* Also update the info_lck-protected copy */
    9153           0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9154           0 :     XLogCtl->RedoRecPtr = lastCheckPoint.redo;
    9155           0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9156             : 
    9157             :     /*
    9158             :      * Prepare to accumulate statistics.
    9159             :      *
    9160             :      * Note: because it is possible for log_checkpoints to change while a
    9161             :      * checkpoint proceeds, we always accumulate stats, even if
    9162             :      * log_checkpoints is currently off.
    9163             :      */
    9164           0 :     MemSet(&CheckpointStats, 0, sizeof(CheckpointStats));
    9165           0 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_start_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    9166             : 
    9167           0 :     if (log_checkpoints)
    9168           0 :         LogCheckpointStart(flags, true);
    9169             : 
    9170           0 :     CheckPointGuts(lastCheckPoint.redo, flags);
    9171             : 
    9172             :     /*
    9173             :      * Remember the prior checkpoint's redo ptr for
    9174             :      * UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate()
    9175             :      */
    9176           0 :     PriorRedoPtr = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo;
    9177             : 
    9178             :     /*
    9179             :      * Update pg_control, using current time.  Check that it still shows
    9180             :      * DB_IN_ARCHIVE_RECOVERY state and an older checkpoint, else do nothing;
    9181             :      * this is a quick hack to make sure nothing really bad happens if somehow
    9182             :      * we get here after the end-of-recovery checkpoint.
    9183             :      */
    9184           0 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9185           0 :     if (ControlFile->state == DB_IN_ARCHIVE_RECOVERY &&
    9186           0 :         ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo < lastCheckPoint.redo)
    9187             :     {
    9188           0 :         ControlFile->checkPoint = lastCheckPointRecPtr;
    9189           0 :         ControlFile->checkPointCopy = lastCheckPoint;
    9190           0 :         ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    9191             : 
    9192             :         /*
    9193             :          * Ensure minRecoveryPoint is past the checkpoint record.  Normally,
    9194             :          * this will have happened already while writing out dirty buffers,
    9195             :          * but not necessarily - e.g. because no buffers were dirtied.  We do
    9196             :          * this because a non-exclusive base backup uses minRecoveryPoint to
    9197             :          * determine which WAL files must be included in the backup, and the
    9198             :          * file (or files) containing the checkpoint record must be included,
    9199             :          * at a minimum. Note that for an ordinary restart of recovery there's
    9200             :          * no value in having the minimum recovery point any earlier than this
    9201             :          * anyway, because redo will begin just after the checkpoint record.
    9202             :          */
    9203           0 :         if (ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint < lastCheckPointEndPtr)
    9204             :         {
    9205           0 :             ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint = lastCheckPointEndPtr;
    9206           0 :             ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI = lastCheckPoint.ThisTimeLineID;
    9207             : 
    9208             :             /* update local copy */
    9209           0 :             minRecoveryPoint = ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint;
    9210           0 :             minRecoveryPointTLI = ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI;
    9211             :         }
    9212           0 :         if (flags & CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN)
    9213           0 :             ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNED_IN_RECOVERY;
    9214           0 :         UpdateControlFile();
    9215             :     }
    9216           0 :     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9217             : 
    9218             :     /*
    9219             :      * Update the average distance between checkpoints/restartpoints if the
    9220             :      * prior checkpoint exists.
    9221             :      */
    9222           0 :     if (PriorRedoPtr != InvalidXLogRecPtr)
    9223           0 :         UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate(RedoRecPtr - PriorRedoPtr);
    9224             : 
    9225             :     /*
    9226             :      * Delete old log files, those no longer needed for last restartpoint to
    9227             :      * prevent the disk holding the xlog from growing full.
    9228             :      */
    9229           0 :     XLByteToSeg(RedoRecPtr, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    9230             : 
    9231             :     /*
    9232             :      * Retreat _logSegNo using the current end of xlog replayed or received,
    9233             :      * whichever is later.
    9234             :      */
    9235           0 :     receivePtr = GetWalRcvWriteRecPtr(NULL, NULL);
    9236           0 :     replayPtr = GetXLogReplayRecPtr(&replayTLI);
    9237           0 :     endptr = (receivePtr < replayPtr) ? replayPtr : receivePtr;
    9238           0 :     KeepLogSeg(endptr, &_logSegNo);
    9239           0 :     _logSegNo--;
    9240             : 
    9241             :     /*
    9242             :      * Try to recycle segments on a useful timeline. If we've been promoted
    9243             :      * since the beginning of this restartpoint, use the new timeline chosen
    9244             :      * at end of recovery (RecoveryInProgress() sets ThisTimeLineID in that
    9245             :      * case). If we're still in recovery, use the timeline we're currently
    9246             :      * replaying.
    9247             :      *
    9248             :      * There is no guarantee that the WAL segments will be useful on the
    9249             :      * current timeline; if recovery proceeds to a new timeline right after
    9250             :      * this, the pre-allocated WAL segments on this timeline will not be used,
    9251             :      * and will go wasted until recycled on the next restartpoint. We'll live
    9252             :      * with that.
    9253             :      */
    9254           0 :     if (RecoveryInProgress())
    9255           0 :         ThisTimeLineID = replayTLI;
    9256             : 
    9257           0 :     RemoveOldXlogFiles(_logSegNo, RedoRecPtr, endptr);
    9258             : 
    9259             :     /*
    9260             :      * Make more log segments if needed.  (Do this after recycling old log
    9261             :      * segments, since that may supply some of the needed files.)
    9262             :      */
    9263           0 :     PreallocXlogFiles(endptr);
    9264             : 
    9265             :     /*
    9266             :      * ThisTimeLineID is normally not set when we're still in recovery.
    9267             :      * However, recycling/preallocating segments above needed ThisTimeLineID
    9268             :      * to determine which timeline to install the segments on. Reset it now,
    9269             :      * to restore the normal state of affairs for debugging purposes.
    9270             :      */
    9271           0 :     if (RecoveryInProgress())
    9272           0 :         ThisTimeLineID = 0;
    9273             : 
    9274             :     /*
    9275             :      * Truncate pg_subtrans if possible.  We can throw away all data before
    9276             :      * the oldest XMIN of any running transaction.  No future transaction will
    9277             :      * attempt to reference any pg_subtrans entry older than that (see Asserts
    9278             :      * in subtrans.c).  When hot standby is disabled, though, we mustn't do
    9279             :      * this because StartupSUBTRANS hasn't been called yet.
    9280             :      */
    9281           0 :     if (EnableHotStandby)
    9282           0 :         TruncateSUBTRANS(GetOldestXmin(NULL, PROCARRAY_FLAGS_DEFAULT));
    9283             : 
    9284             :     /* Real work is done, but log and update before releasing lock. */
    9285           0 :     LogCheckpointEnd(true);
    9286             : 
    9287           0 :     xtime = GetLatestXTime();
    9288           0 :     ereport((log_checkpoints ? LOG : DEBUG2),
    9289             :             (errmsg("recovery restart point at %X/%X",
    9290             :                     (uint32) (lastCheckPoint.redo >> 32), (uint32) lastCheckPoint.redo),
    9291             :              xtime ? errdetail("Last completed transaction was at log time %s.",
    9292             :                                timestamptz_to_str(xtime)) : 0));
    9293             : 
    9294           0 :     LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    9295             : 
    9296             :     /*
    9297             :      * Finally, execute archive_cleanup_command, if any.
    9298             :      */
    9299           0 :     if (archiveCleanupCommand && strcmp(archiveCleanupCommand, "") != 0)
    9300           0 :         ExecuteRecoveryCommand(archiveCleanupCommand,
    9301             :                                "archive_cleanup_command",
    9302             :                                false);
    9303             : 
    9304           0 :     return true;
    9305             : }
    9306             : 
    9307             : /*
    9308             :  * Retreat *logSegNo to the last segment that we need to retain because of
    9309             :  * either wal_keep_segments or replication slots.
    9310             :  *
    9311             :  * This is calculated by subtracting wal_keep_segments from the given xlog
    9312             :  * location, recptr and by making sure that that result is below the
    9313             :  * requirement of replication slots.
    9314             :  */
    9315             : static void
    9316          22 : KeepLogSeg(XLogRecPtr recptr, XLogSegNo *logSegNo)
    9317             : {
    9318             :     XLogSegNo   segno;
    9319             :     XLogRecPtr  keep;
    9320             : 
    9321          22 :     XLByteToSeg(recptr, segno, wal_segment_size);
    9322          22 :     keep = XLogGetReplicationSlotMinimumLSN();
    9323             : 
    9324             :     /* compute limit for wal_keep_segments first */
    9325          22 :     if (wal_keep_segments > 0)
    9326             :     {
    9327             :         /* avoid underflow, don't go below 1 */
    9328           0 :         if (segno <= wal_keep_segments)
    9329           0 :             segno = 1;
    9330             :         else
    9331           0 :             segno = segno - wal_keep_segments;
    9332             :     }
    9333             : 
    9334             :     /* then check whether slots limit removal further */
    9335          22 :     if (max_replication_slots > 0 && keep != InvalidXLogRecPtr)
    9336             :     {
    9337             :         XLogSegNo   slotSegNo;
    9338             : 
    9339           0 :         XLByteToSeg(keep, slotSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    9340             : 
    9341           0 :         if (slotSegNo <= 0)
    9342           0 :             segno = 1;
    9343           0 :         else if (slotSegNo < segno)
    9344           0 :             segno = slotSegNo;
    9345             :     }
    9346             : 
    9347             :     /* don't delete WAL segments newer than the calculated segment */
    9348          22 :     if (segno < *logSegNo)
    9349           0 :         *logSegNo = segno;
    9350          22 : }
    9351             : 
    9352             : /*
    9353             :  * Write a NEXTOID log record
    9354             :  */
    9355             : void
    9356          10 : XLogPutNextOid(Oid nextOid)
    9357             : {
    9358          10 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    9359          10 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) (&nextOid), sizeof(Oid));
    9360          10 :     (void) XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_NEXTOID);
    9361             : 
    9362             :     /*
    9363             :      * We need not flush the NEXTOID record immediately, because any of the
    9364             :      * just-allocated OIDs could only reach disk as part of a tuple insert or
    9365             :      * update that would have its own XLOG record that must follow the NEXTOID
    9366             :      * record.  Therefore, the standard buffer LSN interlock applied to those
    9367             :      * records will ensure no such OID reaches disk before the NEXTOID record
    9368             :      * does.
    9369             :      *
    9370             :      * Note, however, that the above statement only covers state "within" the
    9371             :      * database.  When we use a generated OID as a file or directory name, we
    9372             :      * are in a sense violating the basic WAL rule, because that filesystem
    9373             :      * change may reach disk before the NEXTOID WAL record does.  The impact
    9374             :      * of this is that if a database crash occurs immediately afterward, we
    9375             :      * might after restart re-generate the same OID and find that it conflicts
    9376             :      * with the leftover file or directory.  But since for safety's sake we
    9377             :      * always loop until finding a nonconflicting filename, this poses no real
    9378             :      * problem in practice. See pgsql-hackers discussion 27-Sep-2006.
    9379             :      */
    9380          10 : }
    9381             : 
    9382             : /*
    9383             :  * Write an XLOG SWITCH record.
    9384             :  *
    9385             :  * Here we just blindly issue an XLogInsert request for the record.
    9386             :  * All the magic happens inside XLogInsert.
    9387             :  *
    9388             :  * The return value is either the end+1 address of the switch record,
    9389             :  * or the end+1 address of the prior segment if we did not need to
    9390             :  * write a switch record because we are already at segment start.
    9391             :  */
    9392             : XLogRecPtr
    9393           0 : RequestXLogSwitch(bool mark_unimportant)
    9394             : {
    9395             :     XLogRecPtr  RecPtr;
    9396             : 
    9397             :     /* XLOG SWITCH has no data */
    9398           0 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    9399             : 
    9400           0 :     if (mark_unimportant)
    9401           0 :         XLogSetRecordFlags(XLOG_MARK_UNIMPORTANT);
    9402           0 :     RecPtr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_SWITCH);
    9403             : 
    9404           0 :     return RecPtr;
    9405             : }
    9406             : 
    9407             : /*
    9408             :  * Write a RESTORE POINT record
    9409             :  */
    9410             : XLogRecPtr
    9411           0 : XLogRestorePoint(const char *rpName)
    9412             : {
    9413             :     XLogRecPtr  RecPtr;
    9414             :     xl_restore_point xlrec;
    9415             : 
    9416           0 :     xlrec.rp_time = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    9417           0 :     strlcpy(xlrec.rp_name, rpName, MAXFNAMELEN);
    9418             : 
    9419           0 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    9420           0 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, sizeof(xl_restore_point));
    9421             : 
    9422           0 :     RecPtr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_RESTORE_POINT);
    9423             : 
    9424           0 :     ereport(LOG,
    9425             :             (errmsg("restore point \"%s\" created at %X/%X",
    9426             :                     rpName, (uint32) (RecPtr >> 32), (uint32) RecPtr)));
    9427             : 
    9428           0 :     return RecPtr;
    9429             : }
    9430             : 
    9431             : /*
    9432             :  * Check if any of the GUC parameters that are critical for hot standby

    9434             :  */
    9435             : static void
    9436           6 : XLogReportParameters(void)
    9437             : {
    9438          12 :     if (wal_level != ControlFile->wal_level ||
    9439          12 :         wal_log_hints != ControlFile->wal_log_hints ||
    9440          12 :         MaxConnections != ControlFile->MaxConnections ||
    9441          12 :         max_worker_processes != ControlFile->max_worker_processes ||
    9442          12 :         max_wal_senders != ControlFile->max_wal_senders ||
    9443          10 :         max_prepared_xacts != ControlFile->max_prepared_xacts ||
    9444           8 :         max_locks_per_xact != ControlFile->max_locks_per_xact ||
    9445           4 :         track_commit_timestamp != ControlFile->track_commit_timestamp)
    9446             :     {
    9447             :         /*
    9448             :          * The change in number of backend slots doesn't need to be WAL-logged
    9449             :          * if archiving is not enabled, as you can't start archive recovery
    9450             :          * with wal_level=minimal anyway. We don't really care about the
    9451             :          * values in pg_control either if wal_level=minimal, but seems better
    9452             :          * to keep them up-to-date to avoid confusion.
    9453             :          */
    9454           2 :         if (wal_level != ControlFile->wal_level || XLogIsNeeded())
    9455             :         {
    9456             :             xl_parameter_change xlrec;
    9457             :             XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    9458             :

    9461           2 :             xlrec.max_wal_senders = max_wal_senders;

    9463           2 :             xlrec.max_locks_per_xact = max_locks_per_xact;
    9464           2 :             xlrec.wal_level = wal_level;
    9465           2 :             xlrec.wal_log_hints = wal_log_hints;
    9466           2 :             xlrec.track_commit_timestamp = track_commit_timestamp;
    9467             :

    9470             :

    9472           2 :             XLogFlush(recptr);
    9473             :         }
    9474             : 
    9475           2 :         ControlFile->MaxConnections = MaxConnections;
    9476           2 :         ControlFile->max_worker_processes = max_worker_processes;
    9477           2 :         ControlFile->max_wal_senders = max_wal_senders;
    9478           2 :         ControlFile->max_prepared_xacts = max_prepared_xacts;
    9479           2 :         ControlFile->max_locks_per_xact = max_locks_per_xact;
    9480           2 :         ControlFile->wal_level = wal_level;
    9481           2 :         ControlFile->wal_log_hints = wal_log_hints;
    9482           2 :         ControlFile->track_commit_timestamp = track_commit_timestamp;
    9483           2 :         UpdateControlFile();
    9484             :     }
    9485           6 : }
    9486             : 
    9487             : /*
    9488             :  * Update full_page_writes in shared memory, and write an
    9489             :  * XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record if necessary.
    9490             :  *
    9491             :  * Note: this function assumes there is no other process running
    9492             :  * concurrently that could update it.
    9493             :  */
    9494             : void
    9495           8 : UpdateFullPageWrites(void)
    9496             : {
    9497           8 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    9498             :     bool        recoveryInProgress;
    9499             : 
    9500             :     /*
    9501             :      * Do nothing if full_page_writes has not been changed.
    9502             :      *
    9503             :      * It's safe to check the shared full_page_writes without the lock,
    9504             :      * because we assume that there is no concurrently running process which
    9505             :      * can update it.
    9506             :      */
    9507           8 :     if (fullPageWrites == Insert->fullPageWrites)
    9508          16 :         return;
    9509             : 
    9510             :     /*
    9511             :      * Perform this outside critical section so that the WAL insert
    9512             :      * initialization done by RecoveryInProgress() doesn't trigger an
    9513             :      * assertion failure.
    9514             :      */
    9515           0 :     recoveryInProgress = RecoveryInProgress();
    9516             : 
    9517           0 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    9518             : 
    9519             :     /*
    9520             :      * It's always safe to take full page images, even when not strictly
    9521             :      * required, but not the other round. So if we're setting full_page_writes
    9522             :      * to true, first set it true and then write the WAL record. If we're
    9523             :      * setting it to false, first write the WAL record and then set the global
    9524             :      * flag.
    9525             :      */
    9526           0 :     if (fullPageWrites)
    9527             :     {
    9528           0 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9529           0 :         Insert->fullPageWrites = true;
    9530           0 :         WALInsertLockRelease();
    9531             :     }
    9532             : 
    9533             :     /*
    9534             :      * Write an XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record. This allows us to keep track of
    9535             :      * full_page_writes during archive recovery, if required.
    9536             :      */
    9537           0 :     if (XLogStandbyInfoActive() && !recoveryInProgress)
    9538             :     {
    9539           0 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    9540           0 :         XLogRegisterData((char *) (&fullPageWrites), sizeof(bool));
    9541             : 
    9542           0 :         XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_FPW_CHANGE);
    9543             :     }
    9544             : 
    9545           0 :     if (!fullPageWrites)
    9546             :     {
    9547           0 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9548           0 :         Insert->fullPageWrites = false;
    9549           0 :         WALInsertLockRelease();
    9550             :     }
    9551           0 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    9552             : }
    9553             : 
    9554             : /*
    9555             :  * Check that it's OK to switch to new timeline during recovery.
    9556             :  *
    9557             :  * 'lsn' is the address of the shutdown checkpoint record we're about to
    9558             :  * replay. (Currently, timeline can only change at a shutdown checkpoint).
    9559             :  */
    9560             : static void
    9561           0 : checkTimeLineSwitch(XLogRecPtr lsn, TimeLineID newTLI, TimeLineID prevTLI)
    9562             : {
    9563             :     /* Check that the record agrees on what the current (old) timeline is */
    9564           0 :     if (prevTLI != ThisTimeLineID)
    9565           0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    9566             :                 (errmsg("unexpected previous timeline ID %u (current timeline ID %u) in checkpoint record",
    9567             :                         prevTLI, ThisTimeLineID)));
    9568             : 
    9569             :     /*
    9570             :      * The new timeline better be in the list of timelines we expect to see,
    9571             :      * according to the timeline history. It should also not decrease.
    9572             :      */
    9573           0 :     if (newTLI < ThisTimeLineID || !tliInHistory(newTLI, expectedTLEs))
    9574           0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    9575             :                 (errmsg("unexpected timeline ID %u (after %u) in checkpoint record",
    9576             :                         newTLI, ThisTimeLineID)));
    9577             : 
    9578             :     /*
    9579             :      * If we have not yet reached min recovery point, and we're about to
    9580             :      * switch to a timeline greater than the timeline of the min recovery
    9581             :      * point: trouble. After switching to the new timeline, we could not
    9582             :      * possibly visit the min recovery point on the correct timeline anymore.
    9583             :      * This can happen if there is a newer timeline in the archive that
    9584             :      * branched before the timeline the min recovery point is on, and you
    9585             :      * attempt to do PITR to the new timeline.
    9586             :      */
    9587           0 :     if (!XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(minRecoveryPoint) &&
    9588           0 :         lsn < minRecoveryPoint &&
    9589           0 :         newTLI > minRecoveryPointTLI)
    9590           0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    9591             :                 (errmsg("unexpected timeline ID %u in checkpoint record, before reaching minimum recovery point %X/%X on timeline %u",
    9592             :                         newTLI,
    9593             :                         (uint32) (minRecoveryPoint >> 32),
    9594             :                         (uint32) minRecoveryPoint,
    9595             :                         minRecoveryPointTLI)));
    9596             : 
    9597             :     /* Looks good */
    9598           0 : }
    9599             : 
    9600             : /*
    9601             :  * XLOG resource manager's routines

    9604             :  * not all record types are related to control file updates.

    9606             : void
    9607           0 : xlog_redo(XLogReaderState *record)
    9608             : {
    9609           0 :     uint8       info = XLogRecGetInfo(record) & ~XLR_INFO_MASK;
    9610           0 :     XLogRecPtr  lsn = record->EndRecPtr;
    9611             : 
    9612             :     /* in XLOG rmgr, backup blocks are only used by XLOG_FPI records */
    9613           0 :     Assert(info == XLOG_FPI || info == XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT ||
    9614             :            !XLogRecHasAnyBlockRefs(record));
    9615             : 
    9616           0 :     if (info == XLOG_NEXTOID)
    9617             :     {
    9618             :         Oid         nextOid;
    9619             : 
    9620             :         /*
    9621             :          * We used to try to take the maximum of ShmemVariableCache->nextOid
    9622             :          * and the recorded nextOid, but that fails if the OID counter wraps
    9623             :          * around.  Since no OID allocation should be happening during replay
    9624             :          * anyway, better to just believe the record exactly.  We still take
    9625             :          * OidGenLock while setting the variable, just in case.
    9626             :          */
    9627           0 :         memcpy(&nextOid, XLogRecGetData(record), sizeof(Oid));
    9628           0 :         LWLockAcquire(OidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9629           0 :         ShmemVariableCache->nextOid = nextOid;
    9630           0 :         ShmemVariableCache->oidCount = 0;
    9631           0 :         LWLockRelease(OidGenLock);
    9632             :     }
    9633           0 :     else if (info == XLOG_CHECKPOINT_SHUTDOWN)
    9634             :     {

    9637           0 :         memcpy(&checkPoint, XLogRecGetData(record), sizeof(CheckPoint));
    9638             :         /* In a SHUTDOWN checkpoint, believe the counters exactly */
    9639           0 :         LWLockAcquire(XidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);

    9657             : 
    9658             :         /*

    9661             :          * never arrive.

    9726           0 :     else if (info == XLOG_CHECKPOINT_ONLINE)
    9727             :     {
    9728             :         CheckPoint  checkPoint;
    9729             : 
    9730           0 :         memcpy(&checkPoint, XLogRecGetData(record), sizeof(CheckPoint));
    9731             :         /* In an ONLINE checkpoint, treat the XID counter as a minimum */
    9732           0 :         LWLockAcquire(XidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);

    9734             :                                       checkPoint.nextFullXid))
    9735           0 :             ShmemVariableCache->nextFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    9736           0 :         LWLockRelease(XidGenLock);
    9737             : 
    9738             :         /*
    9739             :          * We ignore the nextOid counter in an ONLINE checkpoint, preferring
    9740             :          * to track OID assignment through XLOG_NEXTOID records.  The nextOid
    9741             :          * counter is from the start of the checkpoint and might well be stale
    9742             :          * compared to later XLOG_NEXTOID records.  We could try to take the
    9743             :          * maximum of the nextOid counter and our latest value, but since
    9744             :          * there's no particular guarantee about the speed with which the OID
    9745             :          * counter wraps around, that's a risky thing to do.  In any case,
    9746             :          * users of the nextOid counter are required to avoid assignment of
    9747             :          * duplicates, so that a somewhat out-of-date value should be safe.
    9748             :          */
    9749             : 
    9750             :         /* Handle multixact */
    9751           0 :         MultiXactAdvanceNextMXact(checkPoint.nextMulti,
    9752             :                                   checkPoint.nextMultiOffset);
    9753             : 
    9754             :         /*
    9755             :          * NB: This may perform multixact truncation when replaying WAL
    9756             :          * generated by an older primary.
    9757             :          */
    9758           0 :         MultiXactAdvanceOldest(checkPoint.oldestMulti,
    9759             :                                checkPoint.oldestMultiDB);

    9767             :         /* Update shared-memory copy of checkpoint XID/epoch */
    9768           0 :         SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9769           0 :         XLogCtl->ckptFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    9770           0 :         SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9771             : 
    9772             :         /* TLI should not change in an on-line checkpoint */
    9773           0 :         if (checkPoint.ThisTimeLineID != ThisTimeLineID)

    9778           0 :         RecoveryRestartPoint(&checkPoint);

    9781             :     {
    9782             :         xl_end_of_recovery xlrec;
    9783             : 
    9784           0 :         memcpy(&xlrec, XLogRecGetData(record), sizeof(xl_end_of_recovery));
    9785             : 
    9786             :         /*
    9787             :          * For Hot Standby, we could treat this like a Shutdown Checkpoint,
    9788             :          * but this case is rarer and harder to test, so the benefit doesn't
    9789             :          * outweigh the potential extra cost of maintenance.
    9790             :          */
    9791             : 
    9792             :         /*
    9793             :          * We should've already switched to the new TLI before replaying this
    9794             :          * record.
    9795             :          */
    9796           0 :         if (xlrec.ThisTimeLineID != ThisTimeLineID)
    9797           0 :             ereport(PANIC,
    9798             :                     (errmsg("unexpected timeline ID %u (should be %u) in checkpoint record",
    9799             :                             xlrec.ThisTimeLineID, ThisTimeLineID)));
    9800             :     }
    9801           0 :     else if (info == XLOG_NOOP)
    9802             :     {
    9803             :         /* nothing to do here */
    9804             :     }
    9805           0 :     else if (info == XLOG_SWITCH)
    9806             :     {
    9807             :         /* nothing to do here */
    9808             :     }
    9809           0 :     else if (info == XLOG_RESTORE_POINT)
    9810             :     {
    9811             :         /* nothing to do here */
    9812             :     }
    9813           0 :     else if (info == XLOG_FPI || info == XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT)
    9814             :     {
    9815             :         /*
    9816             :          * Full-page image (FPI) records contain nothing else but a backup
    9817             :          * block (or multiple backup blocks). Every block reference must
    9818             :          * include a full-page image - otherwise there would be no point in
    9819             :          * this record.
    9820             :          *
    9821             :          * No recovery conflicts are generated by these generic records - if a
    9822             :          * resource manager needs to generate conflicts, it has to define a
    9823             :          * separate WAL record type and redo routine.
    9824             :          *
    9825             :          * XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT records are generated when a page needs to be
    9826             :          * WAL- logged because of a hint bit update. They are only generated
    9827             :          * when checksums are enabled. There is no difference in handling
    9828             :          * XLOG_FPI and XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT records, they use a different info

   10007             : /*
   10008             :  * Return the (possible) sync flag used for opening a file, depending on the
   10009             :  * value of the GUC wal_sync_method.
   10010             :  */
   10011             : static int
   10012         608 : get_sync_bit(int method)
   10013             : {
   10014         608 :     int         o_direct_flag = 0;
   10015             : 
   10016             :     /* If fsync is disabled, never open in sync mode */
   10017         608 :     if (!enableFsync)
   10018         608 :         return 0;
   10019             : 
   10020             :     /*
   10021             :      * Optimize writes by bypassing kernel cache with O_DIRECT when using
   10022             :      * O_SYNC/O_FSYNC and O_DSYNC.  But only if archiving and streaming are
   10023             :      * disabled, otherwise the archive command or walsender process will read
   10024             :      * the WAL soon after writing it, which is guaranteed to cause a physical
   10025             :      * read if we bypassed the kernel cache. We also skip the
   10026             :      * posix_fadvise(POSIX_FADV_DONTNEED) call in XLogFileClose() for the same
   10027             :      * reason.
   10028             :      *
   10029             :      * Never use O_DIRECT in walreceiver process for similar reasons; the WAL
   10030             :      * written by walreceiver is normally read by the startup process soon
   10031             :      * after its written. Also, walreceiver performs unaligned writes, which
   10032             :      * don't work with O_DIRECT, so it is required for correctness too.
   10033             :      */
   10034           0 :     if (!XLogIsNeeded() && !AmWalReceiverProcess())
   10035           0 :         o_direct_flag = PG_O_DIRECT;
   10036             : 
   10037           0 :     switch (method)
   10038             :     {
   10039             :             /*
   10040             :              * enum values for all sync options are defined even if they are
   10041             :              * not supported on the current platform.  But if not, they are
   10042             :              * not included in the enum option array, and therefore will never
   10043             :              * be seen here.
   10044             :              */
   10045             :         case SYNC_METHOD_FSYNC:
   10046             :         case SYNC_METHOD_FSYNC_WRITETHROUGH:
   10047             :         case SYNC_METHOD_FDATASYNC:
   10048           0 :             return 0;
   10049             : #ifdef OPEN_SYNC_FLAG
   10050             :         case SYNC_METHOD_OPEN:
   10051           0 :             return OPEN_SYNC_FLAG | o_direct_flag;
   10052             : #endif
   10053             : #ifdef OPEN_DATASYNC_FLAG
   10054             :         case SYNC_METHOD_OPEN_DSYNC:
   10055           0 :             return OPEN_DATASYNC_FLAG | o_direct_flag;
   10056             : #endif
   10057             :         default:
   10058             :             /* can't happen (unless we are out of sync with option array) */
   10059           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unrecognized wal_sync_method: %d", method);
   10060             :             return 0;           /* silence warning */
   10061             :     }
   10062             : }

   10064             : /*

   10094             : /*

   10142             : /*

   10145             : char *
   10146           0 : XLogFileNameP(TimeLineID tli, XLogSegNo segno)

   10150           0 :     XLogFileName(result, tli, segno, wal_segment_size);
   10151           0 :     return result;
   10152             : }
   10153             : 
   10154             : /*
   10155             :  * do_pg_start_backup
   10156             :  *
   10157             :  * Utility function called at the start of an online backup. It creates the
   10158             :  * necessary starting checkpoint and constructs the backup label file.
   10159             :  *
   10160             :  * There are two kind of backups: exclusive and non-exclusive. An exclusive
   10161             :  * backup is started with pg_start_backup(), and there can be only one active
   10162             :  * at a time. The backup and tablespace map files of an exclusive backup are
   10163             :  * written to $PGDATA/backup_label and $PGDATA/tablespace_map, and they are
   10164             :  * removed by pg_stop_backup().
   10165             :  *
   10166             :  * A non-exclusive backup is used for the streaming base backups (see
   10167             :  * src/backend/replication/basebackup.c). The difference to exclusive backups
   10168             :  * is that the backup label and tablespace map files are not written to disk.
   10169             :  * Instead, their would-be contents are returned in *labelfile and *tblspcmapfile,
   10170             :  * and the caller is responsible for including them in the backup archive as
   10171             :  * 'backup_label' and 'tablespace_map'. There can be many non-exclusive backups
   10172             :  * active at the same time, and they don't conflict with an exclusive backup
   10173             :  * either.
   10174             :  *
   10175             :  * tblspcmapfile is required mainly for tar format in windows as native windows
   10176             :  * utilities are not able to create symlinks while extracting files from tar.
   10177             :  * However for consistency, the same is used for all platforms.
   10178             :  *
   10179             :  * needtblspcmapfile is true for the cases (exclusive backup and for
   10180             :  * non-exclusive backup only when tar format is used for taking backup)
   10181             :  * when backup needs to generate tablespace_map file, it is used to
   10182             :  * embed escape character before newline character in tablespace path.
   10183             :  *
   10184             :  * Returns the minimum WAL location that must be present to restore from this
   10185             :  * backup, and the corresponding timeline ID in *starttli_p.
   10186             :  *
   10187             :  * Every successfully started non-exclusive backup must be stopped by calling
   10188             :  * do_pg_stop_backup() or do_pg_abort_backup().
   10189             :  *
   10190             :  * It is the responsibility of the caller of this function to verify the
   10191             :  * permissions of the calling user!
   10192             :  */
   10193             : XLogRecPtr
   10194           0 : do_pg_start_backup(const char *backupidstr, bool fast, TimeLineID *starttli_p,
   10195             :                    StringInfo labelfile, List **tablespaces,
   10196             :                    StringInfo tblspcmapfile, bool infotbssize,
   10197             :                    bool needtblspcmapfile)
   10198             : {
   10199           0 :     bool        exclusive = (labelfile == NULL);
   10200           0 :     bool        backup_started_in_recovery = false;
   10201             :     XLogRecPtr  checkpointloc;
   10202             :     XLogRecPtr  startpoint;
   10203             :     TimeLineID  starttli;
   10204             :     pg_time_t   stamp_time;
   10205             :     char        strfbuf[128];
   10206             :     char        xlogfilename[MAXFNAMELEN];
   10207             :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
   10208             :     struct stat stat_buf;
   10209             :     FILE       *fp;
   10210             : 
   10211           0 :     backup_started_in_recovery = RecoveryInProgress();
   10212             : 
   10213             :     /*
   10214             :      * Currently only non-exclusive backup can be taken during recovery.
   10215             :      */
   10216           0 :     if (backup_started_in_recovery && exclusive)
   10217           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10218             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
   10219             :                  errmsg("recovery is in progress"),
   10220             :                  errhint("WAL control functions cannot be executed during recovery.")));
   10221             : 
   10222             :     /*
   10223             :      * During recovery, we don't need to check WAL level. Because, if WAL
   10224             :      * level is not sufficient, it's impossible to get here during recovery.
   10225             :      */
   10226           0 :     if (!backup_started_in_recovery && !XLogIsNeeded())
   10227           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10228             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
   10229             :                  errmsg("WAL level not sufficient for making an online backup"),
   10230             :                  errhint("wal_level must be set to \"replica\" or \"logical\" at server start.")));
   10231             : 
   10232           0 :     if (strlen(backupidstr) > MAXPGPATH)
   10233           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10234             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_PARAMETER_VALUE),
   10235             :                  errmsg("backup label too long (max %d bytes)",
   10236             :                         MAXPGPATH)));
   10237             : 
   10238             :     /*
   10239             :      * Mark backup active in shared memory.  We must do full-page WAL writes
   10240             :      * during an on-line backup even if not doing so at other times, because
   10241             :      * it's quite possible for the backup dump to obtain a "torn" (partially
   10242             :      * written) copy of a database page if it reads the page concurrently with
   10243             :      * our write to the same page.  This can be fixed as long as the first
   10244             :      * write to the page in the WAL sequence is a full-page write. Hence, we
   10245             :      * turn on forcePageWrites and then force a CHECKPOINT, to ensure there
   10246             :      * are no dirty pages in shared memory that might get dumped while the
   10247             :      * backup is in progress without having a corresponding WAL record.  (Once
   10248             :      * the backup is complete, we need not force full-page writes anymore,
   10249             :      * since we expect that any pages not modified during the backup interval
   10250             :      * must have been correctly captured by the backup.)
   10251             :      *
   10252             :      * Note that forcePageWrites has no effect during an online backup from
   10253             :      * the standby.
   10254             :      *
   10255             :      * We must hold all the insertion locks to change the value of
   10256             :      * forcePageWrites, to ensure adequate interlocking against
   10257             :      * XLogInsertRecord().
   10258             :      */
   10259           0 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
   10260           0 :     if (exclusive)
   10261             :     {
   10262             :         /*
   10263             :          * At first, mark that we're now starting an exclusive backup, to
   10264             :          * ensure that there are no other sessions currently running
   10265             :          * pg_start_backup() or pg_stop_backup().
   10266             :          */
   10267           0 :         if (XLogCtl->Insert.exclusiveBackupState != EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_NONE)
   10268             :         {
   10269           0 :             WALInsertLockRelease();
   10270           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   10271             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
   10272             :                      errmsg("a backup is already in progress"),
   10273             :                      errhint("Run pg_stop_backup() and try again.")));
   10274             :         }
   10275           0 :         XLogCtl->Insert.exclusiveBackupState = EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_STARTING;
   10276             :     }
   10277             :     else
   10278           0 :         XLogCtl->Insert.nonExclusiveBackups++;
   10279           0 :     XLogCtl->Insert.forcePageWrites = true;
   10280           0 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
   10281             : 
   10282             :     /* Ensure we release forcePageWrites if fail below */
   10283           0 :     PG_ENSURE_ERROR_CLEANUP(pg_start_backup_callback, (Datum) BoolGetDatum(exclusive));
   10284             :     {
   10285           0 :         bool        gotUniqueStartpoint = false;
   10286             :         DIR        *tblspcdir;
   10287             :         struct dirent *de;
   10288             :         tablespaceinfo *ti;
   10289             :         int         datadirpathlen;
   10290             : 
   10291             :         /*
   10292             :          * Force an XLOG file switch before the checkpoint, to ensure that the
   10293             :          * WAL segment the checkpoint is written to doesn't contain pages with
   10294             :          * old timeline IDs.  That would otherwise happen if you called
   10295             :          * pg_start_backup() right after restoring from a PITR archive: the
   10296             :          * first WAL segment containing the startup checkpoint has pages in
   10297             :          * the beginning with the old timeline ID.  That can cause trouble at
   10298             :          * recovery: we won't have a history file covering the old timeline if
   10299             :          * pg_wal directory was not included in the base backup and the WAL
   10300             :          * archive was cleared too before starting the backup.
   10301             :          *
   10302             :          * This also ensures that we have emitted a WAL page header that has
   10303             :          * XLP_BKP_REMOVABLE off before we emit the checkpoint record.
   10304             :          * Therefore, if a WAL archiver (such as pglesslog) is trying to
   10305             :          * compress out removable backup blocks, it won't remove any that
   10306             :          * occur after this point.
   10307             :          *
   10308             :          * During recovery, we skip forcing XLOG file switch, which means that
   10309             :          * the backup taken during recovery is not available for the special
   10310             :          * recovery case described above.
   10311             :          */
   10312           0 :         if (!backup_started_in_recovery)
   10313           0 :             RequestXLogSwitch(false);
   10314             : 
   10315             :         do
   10316             :         {
   10317             :             bool        checkpointfpw;
   10318             : 
   10319             :             /*
   10320             :              * Force a CHECKPOINT.  Aside from being necessary to prevent torn
   10321             :              * page problems, this guarantees that two successive backup runs
   10322             :              * will have different checkpoint positions and hence different
   10323             :              * history file names, even if nothing happened in between.
   10324             :              *
   10325             :              * During recovery, establish a restartpoint if possible. We use
   10326             :              * the last restartpoint as the backup starting checkpoint. This
   10327             :              * means that two successive backup runs can have same checkpoint
   10328             :              * positions.
   10329             :              *
   10330             :              * Since the fact that we are executing do_pg_start_backup()
   10331             :              * during recovery means that checkpointer is running, we can use
   10332             :              * RequestCheckpoint() to establish a restartpoint.
   10333             :              *
   10334             :              * We use CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE only if requested by user (via
   10335             :              * passing fast = true).  Otherwise this can take awhile.
   10336             :              */
   10337           0 :             RequestCheckpoint(CHECKPOINT_FORCE | CHECKPOINT_WAIT |
   10338             :                               (fast ? CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE : 0));
   10339             : 
   10340             :             /*
   10341             :              * Now we need to fetch the checkpoint record location, and also
   10342             :              * its REDO pointer.  The oldest point in WAL that would be needed
   10343             :              * to restore starting from the checkpoint is precisely the REDO
   10344             :              * pointer.
   10345             :              */
   10346           0 :             LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_SHARED);
   10347           0 :             checkpointloc = ControlFile->checkPoint;
   10348           0 :             startpoint = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo;

   10360             :                  * checkpoint) contain full-page writes.
   10361             :                  */

   10364           0 :                 SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
   10365             : 
   10366           0 :                 if (!checkpointfpw || startpoint <= recptr)
   10367           0 :                     ereport(ERROR,
   10368             :                             (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),

   10370             :                                     "since last restartpoint"),
   10371             :                              errhint("This means that the backup being taken on the standby "
   10372             :                                      "is corrupt and should not be used. "
   10373             :                                      "Enable full_page_writes and run CHECKPOINT on the master, "
   10374             :                                      "and then try an online backup again.")));
   10375             : 
   10376             :                 /*
   10377             :                  * During recovery, since we don't use the end-of-backup WAL
   10378             :                  * record and don't write the backup history file, the
   10379             :                  * starting WAL location doesn't need to be unique. This means
   10380             :                  * that two base backups started at the same time might use
   10381             :                  * the same checkpoint as starting locations.

   10384             :             }
   10385             :

   10387             :              * If two base backups are started at the same time (in WAL sender

   10392             :              * file. Perhaps it would be better generate a separate unique ID
   10393             :              * for each backup instead of forcing another checkpoint, but
   10394             :              * taking a checkpoint right after another is not that expensive
   10395             :              * either because only few buffers have been dirtied yet.
   10396             :              */

   10697             : /*
   10698             :  * do_pg_stop_backup
   10699             :  *
   10700             :  * Utility function called at the end of an online backup. It cleans up the
   10701             :  * backup state and can optionally wait for WAL segments to be archived.
   10702             :  *
   10703             :  * If labelfile is NULL, this stops an exclusive backup. Otherwise this stops
   10704             :  * the non-exclusive backup specified by 'labelfile'.
   10705             :  *
   10706             :  * Returns the last WAL location that must be present to restore from this
   10707             :  * backup, and the corresponding timeline ID in *stoptli_p.
   10708             :  *

   10903             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
   10904             :                  errmsg("the standby was promoted during online backup"),
   10905             :                  errhint("This means that the backup being taken is corrupt "
   10906             :                          "and should not be used. "
   10907             :                          "Try taking another online backup.")));
   10908             : 
   10909             :     /*
   10910             :      * During recovery, we don't write an end-of-backup record. We assume that
   10911             :      * pg_control was backed up last and its minimum recovery point can be
   10912             :      * available as the backup end location. Since we don't have an
   10913             :      * end-of-backup record, we use the pg_control value to check whether
   10914             :      * we've reached the end of backup when starting recovery from this
   10915             :      * backup. We have no way of checking if pg_control wasn't backed up last
   10916             :      * however.
   10917             :      *
   10918             :      * We don't force a switch to new WAL file but it is still possible to
   10919             :      * wait for all the required files to be archived if waitforarchive is
   10920             :      * true. This is okay if we use the backup to start a standby and fetch
   10921             :      * the missing WAL using streaming replication. But in the case of an
   10922             :      * archive recovery, a user should set waitforarchive to true and wait for
   10923             :      * them to be archived to ensure that all the required files are
   10924             :      * available.
   10925             :      *
   10926             :      * We return the current minimum recovery point as the backup end
   10927             :      * location. Note that it can be greater than the exact backup end
   10928             :      * location if the minimum recovery point is updated after the backup of
   10929             :      * pg_control. This is harmless for current uses.
   10930             :      *
   10931             :      * XXX currently a backup history file is for informational and debug
   10932             :      * purposes only. It's not essential for an online backup. Furthermore,
   10933             :      * even if it's created, it will not be archived during recovery because
   10934             :      * an archiver is not invoked. So it doesn't seem worthwhile to write a
   10935             :      * backup history file during recovery.
   10936             :      */
   10937           0 :     if (backup_started_in_recovery)
   10938             :     {
   10939             :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
   10940             : 
   10941             :         /*

   10950           0 :             ereport(ERROR,

   11028             : 
   11029             :     /*
   11030             :      * If archiving is enabled, wait for all the required WAL files to be
   11031             :      * archived before returning. If archiving isn't enabled, the required WAL
   11032             :      * needs to be transported via streaming replication (hopefully with
   11033             :      * wal_keep_segments set high enough), or some more exotic mechanism like
   11034             :      * polling and copying files from pg_wal with script. We have no knowledge
   11035             :      * of those mechanisms, so it's up to the user to ensure that he gets all
   11036             :      * the required WAL.
   11037             :      *
   11038             :      * We wait until both the last WAL file filled during backup and the
   11039             :      * history file have been archived, and assume that the alphabetic sorting
   11040             :      * property of the WAL files ensures any earlier WAL files are safely
   11041             :      * archived as well.
   11042             :      *
   11043             :      * We wait forever, since archive_command is supposed to work and we
   11044             :      * assume the admin wanted his backup to work completely. If you don't
   11045             :      * wish to wait, then either waitforarchive should be passed in as false,
   11046             :      * or you can set statement_timeout.  Also, some notices are issued to
   11047             :      * clue in anyone who might be doing this interactively.
   11048             :      */
   11049             : 
   11050           0 :     if (waitforarchive &&
   11051           0 :         ((!backup_started_in_recovery && XLogArchivingActive()) ||
   11052           0 :          (backup_started_in_recovery && XLogArchivingAlways())))
   11053             :     {
   11054           0 :         XLByteToPrevSeg(stoppoint, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);
   11055           0 :         XLogFileName(lastxlogfilename, stoptli, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);

   11057           0 :         XLByteToSeg(startpoint, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);

   11059             :                               startpoint, wal_segment_size);

   11061           0 :         seconds_before_warning = 60;

   11064           0 :         while (XLogArchiveIsBusy(lastxlogfilename) ||
   11065           0 :                XLogArchiveIsBusy(histfilename))
   11066             :         {
   11067           0 :             CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();

   11069           0 :             if (!reported_waiting && waits > 5)
   11070             :             {
   11071           0 :                 ereport(NOTICE,
   11072             :                         (errmsg("base backup done, waiting for required WAL segments to be archived")));

   11074             :             }
   11075             : 
   11076           0 :             pg_usleep(1000000L);
   11077             : 
   11078           0 :             if (++waits >= seconds_before_warning)
   11079             :             {
   11080           0 :                 seconds_before_warning *= 2;    /* This wraps in >10 years... */

   11086             :                                  "but the database backup will not be usable without all the WAL segments.")));

   11094           0 :         ereport(NOTICE,

   11104             : 
   11105             : 
   11106             : /*
   11107             :  * do_pg_abort_backup: abort a running backup
   11108             :  *
   11109             :  * This does just the most basic steps of do_pg_stop_backup(), by taking the
   11110             :  * system out of backup mode, thus making it a lot more safe to call from
   11111             :  * an error handler.
   11112             :  *
   11113             :  * NB: This is only for aborting a non-exclusive backup that doesn't write
   11114             :  * backup_label. A backup started with pg_start_backup() needs to be finished
   11115             :  * with pg_stop_backup().
   11116             :  */
   11117             : void

   11125           0 :         return;
   11126             :

   11130           0 :     XLogCtl->Insert.nonExclusiveBackups--;

   11132           0 :     if (XLogCtl->Insert.exclusiveBackupState == EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_NONE &&

   11199           0 :     *oldtli = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.ThisTimeLineID;

   11201           0 : }
   11202             : 
   11203             : /*
   11204             :  * read_backup_label: check to see if a backup_label file is present
   11205             :  *
   11206             :  * If we see a backup_label during recovery, we assume that we are recovering
   11207             :  * from a backup dump file, and we therefore roll forward from the checkpoint
   11208             :  * identified by the label file, NOT what pg_control says.  This avoids the
   11209             :  * problem that pg_control might have been archived one or more checkpoints
   11210             :  * later than the start of the dump, and so if we rely on it as the start
   11211             :  * point, we will fail to restore a consistent database state.
   11212             :  *
   11213             :  * Returns true if a backup_label was found (and fills the checkpoint
   11214             :  * location and its REDO location into *checkPointLoc and RedoStartLSN,
   11215             :  * respectively); returns false if not. If this backup_label came from a
   11216             :  * streamed backup, *backupEndRequired is set to true. If this backup_label
   11217             :  * was created during recovery, *backupFromStandby is set to true.
   11218             :  */
   11219             : static bool
   11220           6 : read_backup_label(XLogRecPtr *checkPointLoc, bool *backupEndRequired,
   11221             :                   bool *backupFromStandby)
   11222             : {
   11223             :     char        startxlogfilename[MAXFNAMELEN];
   11224             :     TimeLineID  tli_from_walseg,
   11225             :                 tli_from_file;
   11226             :     FILE       *lfp;
   11227             :     char        ch;
   11228             :     char        backuptype[20];
   11229             :     char        backupfrom[20];
   11230             :     char        backuplabel[MAXPGPATH];
   11231             :     char        backuptime[128];
   11232             :     uint32      hi,
   11233             :                 lo;
   11234             : 
   11235           6 :     *backupEndRequired = false;
   11236           6 :     *backupFromStandby = false;
   11237             : 
   11238             :     /*
   11239             :      * See if label file is present
   11240             :      */
   11241           6 :     lfp = AllocateFile(BACKUP_LABEL_FILE, "r");
   11242           6 :     if (!lfp)
   11243             :     {
   11244           6 :         if (errno != ENOENT)
   11245           0 :             ereport(FATAL,
   11246             :                     (errcode_for_file_access(),
   11247             :                      errmsg("could not read file \"%s\": %m",
   11248             :                             BACKUP_LABEL_FILE)));
   11249           6 :         return false;           /* it's not there, all is fine */
   11250             :     }
   11251             : 
   11252             :     /*
   11253             :      * Read and parse the START WAL LOCATION and CHECKPOINT lines (this code
   11254             :      * is pretty crude, but we are not expecting any variability in the file
   11255             :      * format).
   11256             :      */
   11257           0 :     if (fscanf(lfp, "START WAL LOCATION: %X/%X (file %08X%16s)%c",

   11274             :      */

   11293             :      * happens. That's fine as only minor consistency checks are done

   11332             : 
   11333             : /*
   11334             :  * read_tablespace_map: check to see if a tablespace_map file is present
   11335             :  *
   11336             :  * If we see a tablespace_map file during recovery, we assume that we are
   11337             :  * recovering from a backup dump file, and we therefore need to create symlinks
   11338             :  * as per the information present in tablespace_map file.
   11339             :  *
   11340             :  * Returns true if a tablespace_map file was found (and fills the link
   11341             :  * information for all the tablespace links present in file); returns false
   11342             :  * if not.
   11343             :  */
   11344             : static bool
   11345           0 : read_tablespace_map(List **tablespaces)
   11346             : {
   11347             :     tablespaceinfo *ti;
   11348             :     FILE       *lfp;
   11349             :     char        tbsoid[MAXPGPATH];
   11350             :     char       *tbslinkpath;
   11351             :     char        str[MAXPGPATH];
   11352             :     int         ch,
   11353           0 :                 prev_ch = -1,
   11354           0 :                 i = 0,
   11355             :                 n;
   11356             : 
   11357             :     /*
   11358             :      * See if tablespace_map file is present
   11359             :      */
   11360           0 :     lfp = AllocateFile(TABLESPACE_MAP, "r");
   11361           0 :     if (!lfp)
   11362             :     {
   11363           0 :         if (errno != ENOENT)
   11364           0 :             ereport(FATAL,
   11365             :                     (errcode_for_file_access(),
   11366             :                      errmsg("could not read file \"%s\": %m",
   11367             :                             TABLESPACE_MAP)));
   11368           0 :         return false;           /* it's not there, all is fine */
   11369             :     }
   11370             : 
   11371             :     /*
   11372             :      * Read and parse the link name and path lines from tablespace_map file
   11373             :      * (this code is pretty crude, but we are not expecting any variability in
   11374             :      * the file format).  While taking backup we embed escape character '\\'
   11375             :      * before newline in tablespace path, so that during reading of
   11376             :      * tablespace_map file, we could distinguish newline in tablespace path
   11377             :      * and end of line.  Now while reading tablespace_map file, remove the
   11378             :      * escape character that has been added in tablespace path during backup.
   11379             :      */

   11381             :     {
   11382           0 :         if ((ch == '\n' || ch == '\r') && prev_ch != '\\')
   11383             :         {
   11384           0 :             str[i] = '\0';

   11386           0 :                 ereport(FATAL,
   11387             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
   11388             :                          errmsg("invalid data in file \"%s\"", TABLESPACE_MAP)));
   11389           0 :             tbslinkpath = str + n;
   11390           0 :             i = 0;
   11391             : 
   11392           0 :             ti = palloc(sizeof(tablespaceinfo));
   11393           0 :             ti->oid = pstrdup(tbsoid);
   11394           0 :             ti->path = pstrdup(tbslinkpath);
   11395             : 
   11396           0 :             *tablespaces = lappend(*tablespaces, ti);
   11397           0 :             continue;
   11398             :         }
   11399           0 :         else if ((ch == '\n' || ch == '\r') && prev_ch == '\\')
   11400           0 :             str[i - 1] = ch;
   11401             :         else
   11402           0 :             str[i++] = ch;
   11403           0 :         prev_ch = ch;
   11404             :     }
   11405             : 
   11406           0 :     if (ferror(lfp) || FreeFile(lfp))
   11407           0 :         ereport(FATAL,
   11408             :                 (errcode_for_file_access(),
   11409             :                  errmsg("could not read file \"%s\": %m",
   11410             :                         TABLESPACE_MAP)));
   11411             : 
   11412           0 :     return true;
   11413             : }
