   11448             : 
   11449             : /*
   11450             :  * CancelBackup: rename the "backup_label" and "tablespace_map"
   11451             :  *               files to cancel backup mode
   11452             :  *
   11453             :  * If the "backup_label" file exists, it will be renamed to "backup_label.old".
   11454             :  * Similarly, if the "tablespace_map" file exists, it will be renamed to
   11455             :  * "tablespace_map.old".
   11456             :  *
   11457             :  * Note that this will render an online backup in progress
   11458             :  * useless. To correctly finish an online backup, pg_stop_backup must be
   11459             :  * called.
   11460             :  */
   11461             : void
   11462           2 : CancelBackup(void)
   11463             : {
   11464             :     struct stat stat_buf;
   11465             : 
   11466             :     /* if the backup_label file is not there, return */
   11467           2 :     if (stat(BACKUP_LABEL_FILE, &stat_buf) < 0)
   11468           4 :         return;
   11469             : 
   11470             :     /* remove leftover file from previously canceled backup if it exists */
   11471           0 :     unlink(BACKUP_LABEL_OLD);
   11472             : 
   11473           0 :     if (durable_rename(BACKUP_LABEL_FILE, BACKUP_LABEL_OLD, DEBUG1) != 0)
   11474             :     {
   11475           0 :         ereport(WARNING,
   11476             :                 (errcode_for_file_access(),

   11481             :     }
   11482             : 
   11483             :     /* if the tablespace_map file is not there, return */
   11484           0 :     if (stat(TABLESPACE_MAP, &stat_buf) < 0)
   11485             :     {
   11486           0 :         ereport(LOG,

   11489             :                            BACKUP_LABEL_FILE, BACKUP_LABEL_OLD)));
   11490           0 :         return;
   11491             :     }
   11492             : 
   11493             :     /* remove leftover file from previously canceled backup if it exists */
   11494           0 :     unlink(TABLESPACE_MAP_OLD);
   11495             : 
   11496           0 :     if (durable_rename(TABLESPACE_MAP, TABLESPACE_MAP_OLD, DEBUG1) == 0)
   11497             :     {

   11504             :     }
   11505             :     else
   11506             :     {
   11507           0 :         ereport(WARNING,

   11513             :                            TABLESPACE_MAP, TABLESPACE_MAP_OLD)));
   11514             :     }
   11515             : }
   11516             : 
   11517             : /*
   11518             :  * Read the XLOG page containing RecPtr into readBuf (if not read already).
   11519             :  * Returns number of bytes read, if the page is read successfully, or -1
   11520             :  * in case of errors.  When errors occur, they are ereport'ed, but only
   11521             :  * if they have not been previously reported.
   11522             :  *
   11523             :  * This is responsible for restoring files from archive as needed, as well
   11524             :  * as for waiting for the requested WAL record to arrive in standby mode.
   11525             :  *
   11526             :  * 'emode' specifies the log level used for reporting "file not found" or
   11527             :  * "end of WAL" situations in archive recovery, or in standby mode when a
   11528             :  * trigger file is found. If set to WARNING or below, XLogPageRead() returns
   11529             :  * false in those situations, on higher log levels the ereport() won't
   11530             :  * return.
   11531             :  *
   11532             :  * In standby mode, if after a successful return of XLogPageRead() the
   11533             :  * caller finds the record it's interested in to be broken, it should
   11534             :  * ereport the error with the level determined by
   11535             :  * emode_for_corrupt_record(), and then set lastSourceFailed
   11536             :  * and call XLogPageRead() again with the same arguments. This lets
   11537             :  * XLogPageRead() to try fetching the record from another source, or to
   11538             :  * sleep and retry.
   11539             :  */
   11540             : static int
   11541          10 : XLogPageRead(XLogReaderState *xlogreader, XLogRecPtr targetPagePtr, int reqLen,
   11542             :              XLogRecPtr targetRecPtr, char *readBuf)
   11543             : {
   11544          10 :     XLogPageReadPrivate *private =
   11545             :     (XLogPageReadPrivate *) xlogreader->private_data;
   11546          10 :     int         emode = private->emode;
   11547             :     uint32      targetPageOff;
   11548             :     XLogSegNo   targetSegNo PG_USED_FOR_ASSERTS_ONLY;
   11549             :     int         r;
   11550             : 
   11551          10 :     XLByteToSeg(targetPagePtr, targetSegNo, wal_segment_size);
   11552          10 :     targetPageOff = XLogSegmentOffset(targetPagePtr, wal_segment_size);
   11553             : 
   11554             :     /*
   11555             :      * See if we need to switch to a new segment because the requested record
   11556             :      * is not in the currently open one.
   11557             :      */
   11558          14 :     if (readFile >= 0 &&
   11559           4 :         !XLByteInSeg(targetPagePtr, readSegNo, wal_segment_size))
   11560             :     {
   11561             :         /*
   11562             :          * Request a restartpoint if we've replayed too much xlog since the
   11563             :          * last one.
   11564             :          */
   11565           0 :         if (bgwriterLaunched)
   11566             :         {
   11567           0 :             if (XLogCheckpointNeeded(readSegNo))
   11568             :             {
   11569           0 :                 (void) GetRedoRecPtr();
   11570           0 :                 if (XLogCheckpointNeeded(readSegNo))
   11571           0 :                     RequestCheckpoint(CHECKPOINT_CAUSE_XLOG);
   11572             :             }
   11573             :         }
   11574             : 
   11575           0 :         close(readFile);
   11576           0 :         readFile = -1;
   11577           0 :         readSource = 0;
   11578             :     }
   11579             : 
   11580          10 :     XLByteToSeg(targetPagePtr, readSegNo, wal_segment_size);
   11581             : 
   11582             : retry:
   11583             :     /* See if we need to retrieve more data */
   11584          14 :     if (readFile < 0 ||
   11585           4 :         (readSource == XLOG_FROM_STREAM &&
   11586           0 :          receivedUpto < targetPagePtr + reqLen))
   11587             :     {
   11588          12 :         if (!WaitForWALToBecomeAvailable(targetPagePtr + reqLen,
   11589           6 :                                          private->randAccess,
   11590           6 :                                          private->fetching_ckpt,
   11591             :                                          targetRecPtr))
   11592             :         {
   11593           0 :             if (readFile >= 0)
   11594           0 :                 close(readFile);
   11595           0 :             readFile = -1;
   11596           0 :             readLen = 0;
   11597           0 :             readSource = 0;
   11598             : 
   11599           0 :             return -1;
   11600             :         }
   11601             :     }
   11602             : 
   11603             :     /*
   11604             :      * At this point, we have the right segment open and if we're streaming we
   11605             :      * know the requested record is in it.
   11606             :      */
   11607          10 :     Assert(readFile != -1);
   11608             : 
   11609             :     /*
   11610             :      * If the current segment is being streamed from master, calculate how
   11611             :      * much of the current page we have received already. We know the
   11612             :      * requested record has been received, but this is for the benefit of
   11613             :      * future calls, to allow quick exit at the top of this function.
   11614             :      */
   11615          10 :     if (readSource == XLOG_FROM_STREAM)
   11616             :     {
   11617           0 :         if (((targetPagePtr) / XLOG_BLCKSZ) != (receivedUpto / XLOG_BLCKSZ))
   11618           0 :             readLen = XLOG_BLCKSZ;
   11619             :         else
   11620           0 :             readLen = XLogSegmentOffset(receivedUpto, wal_segment_size) -
   11621             :                 targetPageOff;
   11622             :     }
   11623             :     else
   11624          10 :         readLen = XLOG_BLCKSZ;
   11625             : 
   11626             :     /* Read the requested page */
   11627          10 :     readOff = targetPageOff;
   11628             : 
   11629          10 :     pgstat_report_wait_start(WAIT_EVENT_WAL_READ);
   11630          10 :     r = pg_pread(readFile, readBuf, XLOG_BLCKSZ, (off_t) readOff);
   11631          10 :     if (r != XLOG_BLCKSZ)
   11632             :     {
   11633             :         char        fname[MAXFNAMELEN];
   11634           0 :         int         save_errno = errno;
   11635             : 
   11636           0 :         pgstat_report_wait_end();
   11637           0 :         XLogFileName(fname, curFileTLI, readSegNo, wal_segment_size);
   11638           0 :         if (r < 0)
   11639             :         {
   11640           0 :             errno = save_errno;
   11641           0 :             ereport(emode_for_corrupt_record(emode, targetPagePtr + reqLen),
   11642             :                     (errcode_for_file_access(),
   11643             :                      errmsg("could not read from log segment %s, offset %u: %m",
   11644             :                             fname, readOff)));
   11645             :         }
   11646             :         else
   11647           0 :             ereport(emode_for_corrupt_record(emode, targetPagePtr + reqLen),
   11648             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
   11649             :                      errmsg("could not read from log segment %s, offset %u: read %d of %zu",
   11650             :                             fname, readOff, r, (Size) XLOG_BLCKSZ)));
   11651           0 :         goto next_record_is_invalid;
   11652             :     }
   11653          10 :     pgstat_report_wait_end();
   11654             : 
   11655          10 :     Assert(targetSegNo == readSegNo);
   11656          10 :     Assert(targetPageOff == readOff);
   11657          10 :     Assert(reqLen <= readLen);
   11658             : 
   11659          10 :     xlogreader->seg.ws_tli = curFileTLI;
   11660             : 
   11661             :     /*
   11662             :      * Check the page header immediately, so that we can retry immediately if
   11663             :      * it's not valid. This may seem unnecessary, because XLogReadRecord()
   11664             :      * validates the page header anyway, and would propagate the failure up to
   11665             :      * ReadRecord(), which would retry. However, there's a corner case with
   11666             :      * continuation records, if a record is split across two pages such that
   11667             :      * we would need to read the two pages from different sources. For
   11668             :      * example, imagine a scenario where a streaming replica is started up,
   11669             :      * and replay reaches a record that's split across two WAL segments. The
   11670             :      * first page is only available locally, in pg_wal, because it's already
   11671             :      * been recycled in the master. The second page, however, is not present
   11672             :      * in pg_wal, and we should stream it from the master. There is a recycled
   11673             :      * WAL segment present in pg_wal, with garbage contents, however. We would
   11674             :      * read the first page from the local WAL segment, but when reading the
   11675             :      * second page, we would read the bogus, recycled, WAL segment. If we
   11676             :      * didn't catch that case here, we would never recover, because
   11677             :      * ReadRecord() would retry reading the whole record from the beginning.
   11678             :      *
   11679             :      * Of course, this only catches errors in the page header, which is what
   11680             :      * happens in the case of a recycled WAL segment. Other kinds of errors or
   11681             :      * corruption still has the same problem. But this at least fixes the
   11682             :      * common case, which can happen as part of normal operation.
   11683             :      *
   11684             :      * Validating the page header is cheap enough that doing it twice
   11685             :      * shouldn't be a big deal from a performance point of view.
   11686             :      */
   11687          10 :     if (!XLogReaderValidatePageHeader(xlogreader, targetPagePtr, readBuf))
   11688             :     {
   11689             :         /* reset any error XLogReaderValidatePageHeader() might have set */
   11690           0 :         xlogreader->errormsg_buf[0] = '\0';
   11691           0 :         goto next_record_is_invalid;
   11692             :     }
   11693             : 
   11694          10 :     return readLen;
   11695             : 
   11696             : next_record_is_invalid:
   11697           0 :     lastSourceFailed = true;
   11698             : 
   11699           0 :     if (readFile >= 0)
   11700           0 :         close(readFile);
   11701           0 :     readFile = -1;
   11702           0 :     readLen = 0;
   11703           0 :     readSource = 0;
   11704             : 
   11705             :     /* In standby-mode, keep trying */
   11706           0 :     if (StandbyMode)
   11707           0 :         goto retry;
   11708             :     else
   11709           0 :         return -1;
   11710             : }
   11711             : 
   11712             : /*
   11713             :  * Open the WAL segment containing WAL location 'RecPtr'.
   11714             :  *
   11715             :  * The segment can be fetched via restore_command, or via walreceiver having
   11716             :  * streamed the record, or it can already be present in pg_wal. Checking
   11717             :  * pg_wal is mainly for crash recovery, but it will be polled in standby mode
   11718             :  * too, in case someone copies a new segment directly to pg_wal. That is not
   11719             :  * documented or recommended, though.
   11720             :  *
   11721             :  * If 'fetching_ckpt' is true, we're fetching a checkpoint record, and should
   11722             :  * prepare to read WAL starting from RedoStartLSN after this.
   11723             :  *
   11724             :  * 'RecPtr' might not point to the beginning of the record we're interested
   11725             :  * in, it might also point to the page or segment header. In that case,
   11726             :  * 'tliRecPtr' is the position of the WAL record we're interested in. It is
   11727             :  * used to decide which timeline to stream the requested WAL from.
   11728             :  *
   11729             :  * If the record is not immediately available, the function returns false
   11730             :  * if we're not in standby mode. In standby mode, waits for it to become
   11731             :  * available.
   11732             :  *
   11733             :  * When the requested record becomes available, the function opens the file
   11734             :  * containing it (if not open already), and returns true. When end of standby
   11735             :  * mode is triggered by the user, and there is no more WAL available, returns
   11736             :  * false.
   11737             :  */
   11738             : static bool
   11739           6 : WaitForWALToBecomeAvailable(XLogRecPtr RecPtr, bool randAccess,
   11740             :                             bool fetching_ckpt, XLogRecPtr tliRecPtr)
   11741             : {
   11742             :     static TimestampTz last_fail_time = 0;
   11743             :     TimestampTz now;
   11744           6 :     bool        streaming_reply_sent = false;
   11745             : 
   11746             :     /*-------
   11747             :      * Standby mode is implemented by a state machine:
   11748             :      *
   11749             :      * 1. Read from either archive or pg_wal (XLOG_FROM_ARCHIVE), or just
   11750             :      *    pg_wal (XLOG_FROM_PG_WAL)
   11751             :      * 2. Check trigger file
   11752             :      * 3. Read from primary server via walreceiver (XLOG_FROM_STREAM)
   11753             :      * 4. Rescan timelines
   11754             :      * 5. Sleep wal_retrieve_retry_interval milliseconds, and loop back to 1.
   11755             :      *
   11756             :      * Failure to read from the current source advances the state machine to
   11757             :      * the next state.
   11758             :      *
   11759             :      * 'currentSource' indicates the current state. There are no currentSource
   11760             :      * values for "check trigger", "rescan timelines", and "sleep" states,
   11761             :      * those actions are taken when reading from the previous source fails, as
   11762             :      * part of advancing to the next state.
   11763             :      *-------
   11764             :      */
   11765           6 :     if (!InArchiveRecovery)
   11766           6 :         currentSource = XLOG_FROM_PG_WAL;
   11767           0 :     else if (currentSource == 0)
   11768           0 :         currentSource = XLOG_FROM_ARCHIVE;
   11769             : 
   11770             :     for (;;)
   11771             :     {
   11772           6 :         int         oldSource = currentSource;
   11773             : 
   11774             :         /*
   11775             :          * First check if we failed to read from the current source, and
   11776             :          * advance the state machine if so. The failure to read might've
   11777             :          * happened outside this function, e.g when a CRC check fails on a
   11778             :          * record, or within this loop.
   11779             :          */
   11780           6 :         if (lastSourceFailed)
   11781             :         {
   11782           0 :             switch (currentSource)
   11783             :             {
   11784             :                 case XLOG_FROM_ARCHIVE:
   11785             :                 case XLOG_FROM_PG_WAL:
   11786             : 
   11787             :                     /*
   11788             :                      * Check to see if the trigger file exists. Note that we
   11789             :                      * do this only after failure, so when you create the
   11790             :                      * trigger file, we still finish replaying as much as we
   11791             :                      * can from archive and pg_wal before failover.
   11792             :                      */
   11793           0 :                     if (StandbyMode && CheckForStandbyTrigger())
   11794             :                     {
   11795           0 :                         ShutdownWalRcv();
   11796           0 :                         return false;
   11797             :                     }
   11798             : 
   11799             :                     /*
   11800             :                      * Not in standby mode, and we've now tried the archive
   11801             :                      * and pg_wal.
   11802             :                      */
   11803           0 :                     if (!StandbyMode)
   11804           0 :                         return false;
   11805             : 
   11806             :                     /*
   11807             :                      * If primary_conninfo is set, launch walreceiver to try
   11808             :                      * to stream the missing WAL.
   11809             :                      *
   11810             :                      * If fetching_ckpt is true, RecPtr points to the initial
   11811             :                      * checkpoint location. In that case, we use RedoStartLSN
   11812             :                      * as the streaming start position instead of RecPtr, so
   11813             :                      * that when we later jump backwards to start redo at
   11814             :                      * RedoStartLSN, we will have the logs streamed already.

   11835             : 
   11836           0 :                             if (curFileTLI > 0 && tli < curFileTLI)

   11839             :                                      (uint32) tliRecPtr,
   11840             :                                      tli, curFileTLI);
   11841             :                         }

   11843           0 :                         RequestXLogStreaming(tli, ptr, PrimaryConnInfo,
   11844             :                                              PrimarySlotName);
   11845           0 :                         receivedUpto = 0;
   11846             :                     }
   11847             : 
   11848             :                     /*
   11849             :                      * Move to XLOG_FROM_STREAM state in either case. We'll
   11850             :                      * get immediate failure if we didn't launch walreceiver,
   11851             :                      * and move on to the next state.
   11852             :                      */
   11853           0 :                     currentSource = XLOG_FROM_STREAM;
   11854           0 :                     break;
   11855             : 
   11856             :                 case XLOG_FROM_STREAM:
   11857             : 
   11858             :                     /*
   11859             :                      * Failure while streaming. Most likely, we got here
   11860             :                      * because streaming replication was terminated, or
   11861             :                      * promotion was triggered. But we also get here if we
   11862             :                      * find an invalid record in the WAL streamed from master,
   11863             :                      * in which case something is seriously wrong. There's
   11864             :                      * little chance that the problem will just go away, but
   11865             :                      * PANIC is not good for availability either, especially
   11866             :                      * in hot standby mode. So, we treat that the same as
   11867             :                      * disconnection, and retry from archive/pg_wal again. The
   11868             :                      * WAL in the archive should be identical to what was
   11869             :                      * streamed, so it's unlikely that it helps, but one can
   11870             :                      * hope...
   11871             :                      */
   11872             : 
   11873             :                     /*
   11874             :                      * We should be able to move to XLOG_FROM_STREAM
   11875             :                      * only in standby mode.
   11876             :                      */
   11877           0 :                     Assert(StandbyMode);
   11878             : 
   11879             :                     /*
   11880             :                      * Before we leave XLOG_FROM_STREAM state, make sure that
   11881             :                      * walreceiver is not active, so that it won't overwrite
   11882             :                      * WAL that we restore from archive.
   11883             :                      */
   11884           0 :                     if (WalRcvStreaming())
   11885           0 :                         ShutdownWalRcv();
   11886             : 
   11887             :                     /*
   11888             :                      * Before we sleep, re-scan for possible new timelines if

   11899             : 
   11900             :                     /*
   11901             :                      * XLOG_FROM_STREAM is the last state in our state
   11902             :                      * machine, so we've exhausted all the options for
   11903             :                      * obtaining the requested WAL. We're going to loop back
   11904             :                      * and retry from the archive, but if it hasn't been long
   11905             :                      * since last attempt, sleep wal_retrieve_retry_interval
   11906             :                      * milliseconds to avoid busy-waiting.

   11943           6 :             if (InArchiveRecovery)

   12002             :                     {
   12003           0 :                         lastSourceFailed = true;
   12004           0 :                         break;

   12006             : 
   12007             :                     /*

   12011             :                      * WAL from walreceiver and observe that we had already
   12012             :                      * processed everything before the most recent "chunk"
   12013             :                      * that it flushed to disk.  In steady state where we are
   12014             :                      * keeping up with the incoming data, XLogReceiptTime will
   12015             :                      * be updated on each cycle. When we are behind,
   12016             :                      * XLogReceiptTime will not advance, so the grace time
   12017             :                      * allotted to conflicting queries will decrease.

   12076             :                          * After being triggered, we still want to replay all

   12126             : 
   12127             : /*
   12128             :  * Determine what log level should be used to report a corrupt WAL record
   12129             :  * in the current WAL page, previously read by XLogPageRead().
   12130             :  *
   12131             :  * 'emode' is the error mode that would be used to report a file-not-found
   12132             :  * or legitimate end-of-WAL situation.   Generally, we use it as-is, but if
   12133             :  * we're retrying the exact same record that we've tried previously, only
   12134             :  * complain the first time to keep the noise down.  However, we only do when
   12135             :  * reading from pg_wal, because we don't expect any invalid records in archive
   12136             :  * or in records streamed from master. Files in the archive should be complete,
   12137             :  * and we should never hit the end of WAL because we stop and wait for more WAL
   12138             :  * to arrive before replaying it.
   12139             :  *
   12140             :  * NOTE: This function remembers the RecPtr value it was last called with,
   12141             :  * to suppress repeated messages about the same record. Only call this when
   12142             :  * you are about to ereport(), or you might cause a later message to be
   12143             :  * erroneously suppressed.
   12144             :  */
   12145             : static int
   12146           0 : emode_for_corrupt_record(int emode, XLogRecPtr RecPtr)
   12147             : {
   12148             :     static XLogRecPtr lastComplaint = 0;
   12149             : 
   12150           0 :     if (readSource == XLOG_FROM_PG_WAL && emode == LOG)
   12151             :     {
   12152           0 :         if (RecPtr == lastComplaint)
   12153           0 :             emode = DEBUG1;
   12154             :         else
   12155           0 :             lastComplaint = RecPtr;
   12156             :     }
   12157           0 :     return emode;
   12158             : }
   12159             : 
   12160             : /*

   12167             :     struct stat stat_buf;

   12171           0 :         return true;

   12174             :     {

   12176             :          * In 9.1 and 9.2 the postmaster unlinked the promote file inside the

   12179             :          * it should create a full checkpoint before starting up (fallback
   12180             :          * mode). Fast promotion takes precedence.

   12258             : /*

   12268             : 
   12269             : /*
   12270             :  * Schedule a walreceiver wakeup in the main recovery loop.
   12271             :  */
   12272             : void
   12273           0 : XLogRequestWalReceiverReply(void)
   12274             : {
   12275           0 :     doRequestWalReceiverReply = true;
